summary: Paul Merson initially criticized Andros Townsend's England selection, stating Townsend shouldn't be in the squad after being substituted early against Manchester United; Townsend responded with a stunning equaliser for England against Italy and mocked Merson on Twitter, leading Merson to admit he was wrong and praise the goal; however, after Townsend was brought on for only the final seven minutes of Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley, Merson reignited the row by sarcastically tweeting if Townsend had missed the coach, continuing their feud despite Merson's earlier apology.

Chelsea have made a formal offer with conditions to acquire 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto this summer, confirmed by club president Naoki Ogane, who stated the interest is unrelated to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. If he moves, Muto would join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season; Muto, a Japan international with 37 club appearances, 16 goals, 11 caps, and 1 national goal, recently graduated with an economics degree and has not decided on the bid despite calling the offer an honour. A £4million deal is mooted, and Muto would be Chelsea's first Japanese player.

A large-scale Finnish study found babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, with boys particularly prone to weight gain and increased height; researchers compared records of over 12,000 children, revealing that by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, and repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two raised these odds further, suggesting antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by altering gut bacteria that normally consume food, potentially freeing more calories for the body and increasing appetite, though causation wasn't proven, and the study highlights the importance of judicious antibiotic use amid concerns about over-prescription leading to resistant superbugs and links to other childhood health issues like eczema.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists, losing his footing, knocking his bearskin hat against the sentry box, and dropping his rifle; he quickly scrambled up, appeared embarrassed upon realizing the crowd witnessed his fall, and the incident was filmed by tourist David Meadwell, who captured the guard's tumble and subsequent blushes as colleagues marched on, with the Ministry of Defence declining comment on the operational soldier's accident.

A&E networks are remaking the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which attracted over 100 million viewers, with simulcasts planned for 2016 on A&E, Lifetime, and History channels; this new adaptation, co-executive produced by original star LeVar Burton and Mark Wolper (son of the original's producer), will draw more from Alex Haley's novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," consult historical scholars for authenticity, and aim to introduce the story of Kunta Kinte and his descendants to a new generation unfamiliar with it, positioned as an original and contemporary version relevant in the context of Barack Obama's presidency, films like "12 Years a Slave," and ongoing racial unrest regarding police treatment.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978; he alleges being pinned to a chair and groped by male staff on his first day, causing him to leave immediately and later complain, though his complaints were allegedly ignored for years. After hearing about a VIP paedophile ring investigation, he contacted the Palace last year but was rebuffed twice before his complaint was finally passed to police, who are now investigating the historical allegation. A retired royal aide reportedly interviewed denied involvement, and while the Palace pledged full cooperation with any police probe, police declined to comment further.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a viral rap video parodying 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' theme song, viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube; filmed while driving, their lyrics detail their life in Happy Valley, family pressure for grandkids, their surprisingly quick conception, the positive pregnancy test, and the reveal via sonogram, made to inform distant loved ones and filmed in five takes, with Jesse being a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and the couple considering another video upon learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in Gone With the Wind, specifically a gray jacket and skirt ensemble with a black zigzag applique, sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, California, which also offered over 150 other film items. Originally slate blue-gray but faded to light gray with age, the costume was worn in key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and in a shanty town. Saved from disposal, it was acquired for $20 decades ago by James Tumblin, who began collecting film memorabilia in the 1960s and amassed over 300,000 pieces. Other top-selling items included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The 1939 film, celebrating its 75th anniversary, was based on Margaret Mitchell's novel and featured Hattie McDaniel as the first African-American Oscar winner.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing, according to eyewitness accounts; he was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived, suffering minor injuries including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury but was not attacked by the cheetahs, who zoo officials and a visitor believe were frightened by the screaming and stayed away, and the zoo plans to press child endangering charges against the family while closing the exhibit.

A previously decommissioned speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been non-functional for over two years after all fixed devices in the West Midlands were switched off in 2013 due to obsolete technology, has been mysteriously re-angled to point directly at a house's front door; Birmingham City Council, aware of the issue, stated an engineer will visit, the camera may be removed completely, and it will not be included in a planned pilot for new digital cameras, while enforcement now relies on mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrol officers.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association; Bolt confirmed his participation, stating he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, and emphasized Jamaica's successful relay tradition and his commitment to making the country proud while wearing the national colours, with JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressing pleasure at Bolt's availability and anticipating "sprint magic," while the full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Barcelona teammate Dani Alves, along with Neymar's sister Rafaella, attended the Euro League basketball El Clasico between Barcelona and Real Madrid, where Barcelona secured a narrow 85-80 victory, though Real Madrid remained top of their division on points difference. This support followed Neymar captaining Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile, during which he endured brutal challenges including an apparent stamp from Gary Medel, and preceded Barcelona's return to La Liga competition against Celta Vigo, as they aimed for a treble after moving four points clear at the top with a prior El Clasico win.

Italy is facing a rising wave of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued from Friday to Monday alone, according to the Italian coast guard. Save the Children reported 400 migrants could be missing after a capsizing about 80 miles off Libya, involving a ship carrying 550 people and resulting in 145 rescued, though the coast guard stated it cannot confirm the incident as search operations found no evidence of such a boat. There has been a recent upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy and corresponding rescues; the IOM reported over 10,000 migrant arrivals in Italy in early 2015, with 2,000 rescued in one April weekend, primarily from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria using Libya as transit. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since January due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by crews.

Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool last summer, though unaware of the exact reason for the Chile forward's decision to join the north London club for £32 million; Sanchez has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledged Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been leverage during negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona but praised Sanchez's quick adaptation, top qualities, efficiency, work-rate, fighting spirit, and ability to revitalize the team. Ahead of their Premier League clash, Wenger also noted Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has done well since Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury, while dismissing speculation about a potential move for Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome, aiming to ride further than the current 52.491km mark set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix and will compete in the Tour de Yorkshire beforehand, describes the record as a 'holy grail' and expects his attempt will be supported by a capacity 6,000 crowd, with tickets priced £29-£49 going on sale online from April 19 via Sky Tickets, while the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports; he is also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

Serena Williams described her hard-fought Fed Cup victory over Sara Errani as a significant "eye-opener," realizing she is not as prepared for the claycourt season as believed, despite eventually winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 to extend her career record against Errani to 8-0; the US team lost the tie 3-2 due to a heavy doubles defeat, resulting in relegation to World Group II, and Williams acknowledged needing to adapt her hardcourt mindset to clay, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stated the team must work harder to return to the elite World Group next year, notwithstanding Williams' recent Australian Open win which fueled talk of a calendar Grand Slam, though the French Open has historically been her least successful major despite winning it twice.

River Plate are keen to sign Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, though they admit a deal is complicated, and vice president Matias Patanian has openly stated the club "dream of Falcao" and the "doors are open" for the forward who previously spent eight years there from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances after joining at 15; despite Falcao struggling with only four Premier League goals during his loan at Old Trafford, he has been in good form for Colombia, equaling their all-time record with 24 goals after a recent hat-trick, and it remains uncertain if United will exercise their option to keep him or if he will return to Monaco.

Ella Henderson, who rose to fame on The X Factor in 2012 and is known for her long hair, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste as the face of their 2015 "Ready For It" campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign, launched internationally with TV ads featuring her single "Mirror Man", showcases various hairstyles against city backgrounds. Henderson expressed excitement about working with the brand she regularly uses, while her CEO highlighted the natural synergy between the artist and the UK's leading dry shampoo brand for her debut endorsement.

Aaron Siler, 26, wanted on a felony warrant, was fatally shot by Officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after arming himself during a pursuit; Torres is on leave pending investigation. The Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres thanking the community for support, which Siler's family and friends found disrespectful, demanding its removal, stating it felt like thanking Torres for killing Aaron. The association stated the billboard was solely to express gratitude for community support during difficult times, including impacts on the officer and department. The investigation into Siler's death continues, while an earlier shooting by Torres of Terry Knight was ruled justified by the District Attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants who crossed from Pakistan into Negur in Sistan-Baluchestan province, with three militants killed by Iranian forces; the militant group Jaish al Adl, an anti-Iranian Sunni organization from Pakistan's Balochistan, claimed responsibility; Iran requested Pakistan apprehend the survivors and has previously criticized Pakistan for failing to control terrorists; Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism, stated its security agencies are investigating, asked Iran for evidence, and promised to apprehend and prosecute the militants if they entered Pakistan.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, responding to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki during a Diet committee meeting; Nakatani explained jets are scrambled for unidentified objects but reveal only birds or terrestrial objects, not believed to be from space. Inoki, a former wrestler turned politician known for his distinctive appearance, asked about scrambling jets for alien threats and research into visitors, having claimed a UFO sighting himself. This exchange echoes a 2007 discussion by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba about the constitutional legality of defending against space invasion.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in eastern China, 35-year-old passenger Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after he squatted on the rim of a toilet, worrying it might be unclean, and the porcelain fixture collapsed and shattered beneath him, injuring him so severely he needed dozens of stitches; found bleeding after telephoning companions instead of shouting for help, he initially admitted squatting but later told police he was sitting when the poorly built toilet broke, though authorities believe it was an accident and emphasized toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera he placed under the sink in her bathroom, leading police to discover Rebbie had been sexually abusing her from ages 9 to 13 while she slept and filming her and others undressing or showering over a four-year period. Investigators recovered 41 videos, including 34 showing victims showering, some featuring close-ups of children's genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer; he admitted to filming several juveniles but stated he bought the camera specifically to record the 15-year-old victim. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy, is being held on $500,000 bail, and has a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series features fathers in sharp suits leaping dramatically next to their smiling, casually dressed daughters, capturing po-faced teenagers with their jumping fathers; the images, part of a book translating to 'Daughter and Salary Man,' allow typically serious fathers to express a fun side as 'heroes jumping the sky,' sometimes showing pained expressions with age, and are set against Japanese landmarks, generating significant online interest despite little being known about their origin.

Paul Downton's sacking as England managing director has shifted focus towards Kevin Pietersen potentially returning to the England set-up after being controversially axed by Downton in 2014. Pietersen, who last played internationally during England's disastrous 2013/14 Ashes whitewash, attended Surrey's team photo shoot at the KIA Oval where he appeared both deep in thought and jovial, joking with photographers and teammates like Chris Tremlett, while aiming to force his way back into the Test team for this summer's Ashes through Surrey performances. Surrey begins their County Championship campaign at Glamorgan on April 19 and plays Oxford MCCU in a MCC University match first on Sunday.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week; he was initially fired Wednesday due to poor results, reinstated Thursday by owner Angelo Massone, but fired again after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday left the club 16th and six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach this season and will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao regrets his failed season-long loan to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France, as he struggled to regain his pre-serious-knee-injury form, scoring only four goals, and Manchester United is unlikely to exercise the £46 million option to make the transfer permanent; Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco where he could have played and participated in the Champions League, though he acknowledges Falcao was not feeling well there.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday around 12:30pm while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt; he demanded cash from the owner's daughter, who ran out screaming, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer containing approximately $1,500. The robber remains at large, no weapons were used, and police ask anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online, with the owner noting the mask made this incident particularly frightening compared to previous robberies.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and letting him touch her breasts in April the previous year, and was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Following rumors, police investigated a second allegation, leading to her second arrest on Monday after a different 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights (January 18 and 19) in her car across from another Dallas school; she was released on $50,000 bail, and the school district confirmed she remains on leave, preventing contact with students.

A video viewed over 500,000 times online shows a large crocodile swimming through the Puerto Vallarta marina in Mexico holding a dead domestic dog wearing a red collar in its jaws; the dog belonged to the local bike shop owner, and witness Tim Weston stated the curious animal was attacked when it approached the water's edge near a crocodile sanctuary, with crowds observing the croc keeping its catch for hours as the incident prompted horrified reactions on social media, highlighting the common presence of crocodiles in the mangrove-swamp tourist resort area due to urbanization.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton leaving them just two points above the drop zone with only six wins this season; he initially targeted 10 wins for survival now hopes 8 or 9 might suffice, attributing their struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Diame, Chester, Dawson, Jelavic, and Snodgrass, though he believes the squad has enough to stay up and will fight positively in their remaining six tough fixtures including matches against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Meanwhile, Southampton moved up to fifth in the table after the win, despite manager Ronald Koeman needing to intervene when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty meant for James Ward-Prowse, prompting Koeman to reinforce team rules.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the session ended and altering some answers himself, leading the Department for Education to annul the entire school's SATs results; despite admitting unacceptable professional conduct and showing remorse, Guffick claimed he only asked for answers to be made more legible, but a panel found his deliberate actions dishonest and serious, though not fraudulent, resulting in the prohibition order imposed by the Education Secretary.

Anders Lindegaard, despite limited playing time as Manchester United's third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes and being told he can leave after making only 19 league appearances in five seasons since joining from Aalesunds in 2010, enjoys a happy personal life; he married Swedish-Albanian model Misse Beqiri in Mauritius last year, they have a son together, have been dating since 2012, and Beqiri actively posts modeling photos on Instagram to her over 17,000 followers.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson who purchased them after the stadium's 2008 closure, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000, receiving only a $260,000 bid from a Sotheby's employee; Jackson had acquired the letters, installed in 1976, "on a lark" and expressed a desire for a new generation to own this New York icon, promising to visit a US buyer, while a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s sold for $112,500, significantly above its $20,000 to $30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after Sterling was exposed inhaling nitrous oxide and pictures emerged of both players with shisha pipes; Rodgers spoke to them in his office but took no disciplinary action, urging them to learn and wanting to draw a line under the incident. Steven Gerrard is available for Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after a suspension, though Rodgers hasn’t confirmed if he will start. Rodgers emphasized that past near-misses like the title race and League Cup semi-final are part of the learning journey, believing repeated close encounters are necessary before ultimately achieving success.

After returning to London from international duty where Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier, Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil posted a picture relaxing with his dog, captioned 'Home Sweet Home'. Having missed Arsenal's previous match against Newcastle due to illness (dismissed rumors he was at a nightclub), he is expected to start against Liverpool. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has been in excellent form, contributing four assists and three goals, and states he is adapting well to the demanding English football schedule without a winter break, believing he 'fits perfectly' as a player who thrives on frequent matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has refuted speculation about replacing manager Luis Enrique, stating the club is 'very happy' with him despite rumors; Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year contract until 2016, is concentrating on La Liga matches after preparing Barcelona for a win over Valencia, where goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi secured victory, and Bartomeu is impressed with the manager's performance, noting the team remains capable of winning three trophies this season.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool after talks extended from the beginning of the season, replacing his current deal with 14 months left; the new contract, worth approximately £100,000 per week, will run until the summer of 2020, making him the third player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to extend following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. The 24-year-old England international, signed from Sunderland in 2011 for £16million, has significantly improved under Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season, and is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as captain upon the latter's departure to LA Galaxy.

Filipe Luis insists he will stay at Chelsea until his three-year contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him; he expressed happiness at the club, though he struggled to secure the left-back position after joining from Atletico last July. After playing for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, his focus shifts to the Premier League title run-in, where manager Jose Mourinho demands concentration and winning every one of the nine remaining difficult games, a challenge Luis believes the team is prepared to face.

Nathan Hughes initially received a three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee while scoring a try on March 27, leading to North's stretcher removal and subsequent month off due to concussion, but the Fiji-born Wasps player had this suspension sensationally overturned on appeal following widespread criticism and defence from figures within and outside rugby, including Wasps captain James Haskell, fly-half Andy Goode, and others branding the ban a 'joke'; the appeal panel, examining new evidence not available initially, ruled the incident accidental, rescinded the red card, and cleared Hughes of foul play, allowing him to return to action immediately having missed his side's Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon.

Fiery red sunsets in Washington, photographed by Tim Durkan, resulted from smoke particles transported by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean from Siberian wildfires. The fires began on April 14 when farmers burned fields in southeastern Siberia, but strong winds caused them to spread uncontrollably, destroying dozens of villages before being extinguished. The lingering smoke filtered shorter wavelength colors like blues, greens, yellows, and purples from the sunlight, allowing only reds and oranges to penetrate the atmosphere, an effect intensified during sunsets because light travels through more atmosphere. These intense reddish hues will diminish as the smoke dissipates and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her St. Louis driveway just over a month after purchase; police found and returned it on April 1st after a tip from Mick Sexton, revealing the thieves had spray-painted the rims red, added red detailing, and placed orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping" her car, though she subsequently had it professionally cleaned due to strong odors of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor the finder, she created "The Sexton on Wheels" smoothie (banana, pineapple, peach, coconut cream) at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players will each lose £500,000 in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League, as their contracts incentivize performance to meet financial fair play rules. After losing to Manchester United, City is in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool, with the top three qualifying automatically and the fourth-place team needing to win a qualifying round; the squad has a total of around £12 million at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted their season has disintegrated since being joint-top with Chelsea, with seven losses and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' played at Altrincham's Moss Lane, where entry was free and around 1,000 attended; the match featured significant local talent with 13 English players (10 from Manchester) and utilized a formation mirroring United's first team. England youth international Callum Gribbin scored the decisive goal with a delightful free-kick just before the hour mark, following a display of his skills after he was fouled. The result leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-hit City lost both matches in the Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series, showcasing entertaining skills and commitment from both sides that suggest future first-team potential for homegrown players.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' and an inspiration following their 1-1 draw, where Buffon earned his 147th cap and Hart his 50th for England; Hart, ten years younger than Buffon, expressed pride in reaching his milestone at Juventus Stadium, stated he continues learning from watching Buffon's approach, and affirmed his desire to keep playing well for Manchester City and England to accumulate more caps.

Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer burrito delivery in 67 cities, tapping into the $70 billion food delivery market, after previously declining such collaborations; this service will include a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, and follows visits to Chipotle locations by presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, with other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King also pursuing delivery options.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, published an op-ed urging the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 charges; instead, they seek a sentence of life imprisonment without parole and no appeals to spare their family, particularly their two surviving children, from enduring years of reliving the trauma, as the death penalty process would prolong their anguish stemming from the attack that also severely injured their daughter Jane.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a £400 million luxury home for a mystery billionaire, customized over three years to replace typical passenger capacity with features for a single owner who can host guests; the interior includes multiple lounges, a large dining room with adjoining kitchen, a state room, master bedroom, conference room, office/guest room, and an upper deck aeroloft with eight beds, all designed with a hotel-like ambiance far exceeding commercial first class.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo craft to the International Space Station from Florida; while the ascent and Dragon's journey were successful, the attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a drone ship failed because it landed too hard and tipped over, a setback in the company's goal to master sea landings and eventually ground landings to drastically cut space access costs by reusing rockets. The Dragon, carrying over 4,300 pounds of supplies including research equipment and an espresso maker, will dock with the ISS, spend five weeks being unloaded, then be packed with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash before splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS, which SpaceX was the first private company to dock with the station, was a second launch attempt delayed one day by weather.

Priscilla Presley is collaborating with NBC's Today show to host a contest awarding an Elvis-obsessed couple the ultimate wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside Las Vegas's Westgate Hotel (formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows), with the winning duo announced next Monday and marrying on April 23; Priscilla will serve as witness, and the prize includes a free reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show, while she emphasizes the chapel is a first-class, permanent Graceland exhibit without impersonators, requiring couples to submit videos, photos, and an explanation to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, who are four points above them, despite fighting through a tough season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet each played their 47th game of the season in Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equalling a European top-flight appearance record; Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute and Joe Allen sealed the result with his first Anfield goal capitalizing on a defensive mistake. Following poor performances against Manchester United and Arsenal, Henderson stated this win was vital to put things right and maintain pressure on faltering City. Newcastle had a strong penalty shout denied when Dejan Lovren fouled Ayoze Perez, which Allen admitted looked like a spot-kick.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 in Serie A, ending their four-month home winless streak and moving provisionally four points clear of rivals Lazio in the race for Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute, finishing a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made numerous crucial saves in the second half to preserve the lead, as Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches. Security was extremely tight due to past violence, with restricted ticket sales and 1,000 police present, though no incidents occurred. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli saw Lorenzo Insigne return from injury as a late substitute.

Doncaster Rovers have endured an uninspired League One campaign, leaving them in mid-table mediocrity, and their goalless draw against visiting Fleetwood Town, whose own play-off hopes had faded, proved a particularly dull encounter that tested fans' patience; the lack of action presented a challenge for the club's media team, who responded by creating a remarkably concise 27-second match highlights video for YouTube, featuring only 14 seconds of actual footage showing the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux interacts closely with his blood parrot cichlid, gently cupping, massaging, and stroking it by hand within the tank; the fish initially moves away but repeatedly returns to rest in his hand or circle his fingers, seeming to enjoy the interaction and appearing saddened when his hand is removed. This unique relationship developed after Giroux removed two other bullying fish from the tank and began hand-feeding the cichlid frozen blood worms, eventually making it sociable and demanding daily playtime, with Giroux dedicating at least 15 minutes each day to massaging and playing with his pet. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team is marked by a reminder of his past locker-punching incident and fiery reputation, including clashes with Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson, but coach Peter Moores successfully advised him on controlling his aggression and responding positively. England values Stokes' character and natural exuberance as a contrast to robotic players, recognizing his potential to deliver runs and wickets, but acknowledges the need for careful man-management, allowing controlled aggression while avoiding pigeon-holing and ensuring highs and lows are accepted. Despite potential selection pressure from including a second spinner like Adil Rashid, the team is committed to playing both Stokes and Chris Jordan as much as possible to help them develop and reach their full potential in the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out, with both teams tied on 11 points in Group B but Belgium leading due to superior goal difference, marking Wales' best chance to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. The intense ticket demand followed Wales' comprehensive 3-0 victory over Israel, where Gareth Bale scored, boosting expectations for qualification, and the match will be held at Cardiff City Stadium as preferred by the squad and mandated by UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days, rather than the larger Millennium Stadium.

England coach John Peacock named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions, who won last year against Holland and qualified with a 100% record, face Group D opponents Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting against Italy on May 7; the squad includes Premier League talent like Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo (Chelsea), Chris Willock and first-time call-up Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal), and recalled Liverpool duo Trent Arnold and Herbie Kane who missed qualifiers, with subsequent matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, considered one of the Belgian club's top youth talents who has also attracted attention from Arsenal and Barcelona; Patoulidis previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies, and City have held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock regarding compensation as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future by acquiring the promising teenager.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death in a Fulham flat at the end of March, having suffered fatal head and neck injuries; a 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning, while Scotland Yard, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, appeals for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, emphasizing their commitment to solving the case, though the role of her profession remains unconfirmed.

Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages and buried one child named Daniel James, had £207 stolen from money saved for his £500 gravestone, later accusing her housemate and friend Jamie of the theft on The Jeremy Kyle Show; after a lie detector test revealed Jamie stole it, he confessed via Facebook message but blamed his girlfriend Carol, leading Dawn to express deep betrayal and anguish over the violation of her memorial for her son before storming off the set in tears.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, the ill, and elderly, who were captured during their 2014 takeover of northern Iraqi towns; the release, coordinated with Arab tribal leaders, saw the freed individuals received by Peshmerga forces and transported to Irbil, though the motivation remained unclear. ISIS's conquest, particularly of Sinjar, caused a major humanitarian crisis, displacing hundreds of thousands of Yazidis, a small ancient religious minority (less than 1% of Iraq's population) long persecuted and targeted by ISIS with massacres, enslavement of women, and allegations of mass rape. The international coalition responded with airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS, following previous releases of Yazidi captives.

Harry Kane, known for his animated goal celebrations on the pitch this season, is now featured in an off-pitch animation produced by Copa90, which showcases his best goals and celebrations, including strikes against Chelsea, Arsenal, Newcastle, and his England debut; nominated for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, Kane competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize, with the video titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?" released ahead of the Sunday awards ceremony.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers remaining as Liverpool manager despite three trophyless seasons and likely missing Champions League qualification, stating his future shouldn't hinge on one game and citing new players needing time to bed in; Carragher believes Rodgers, players, and staff will aim for trophies and a top-four finish next season, stressing the manager must identify improvements and that future signings will be crucial; Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation, providing coaching in deprived Merseyside schools and expressing his desire to help youngsters from underprivileged areas like his hometown Bootle, inspired by the support he received growing up in the tight-knit Liverpool community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly coloured plastic Nerf gun confiscated and was frisked by security at East Midlands Airport after the toy was flagged by X-ray scanners during his family's flight to Lanzarote; his father Phil criticised the checks as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous' due to the apparent harmlessness of the item and the rush to catch their flight. The family bought James a replacement gun after their holiday, and the airport apologised for the inconvenience while defending the action, stating they must prohibit items resembling prohibited ones like replica guns, as mandated by government security regulations set by the Department for Transport.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree advertisement seeking a girlfriend or wife with specific requirements: she must love pets, preferably be a non-drinker and non-smoker, be fit and attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with her hands, a good cook, great in bed, enjoy the outdoors yet also act like a princess when needed. In return, he offers free gym membership, a phone of her choice, potential company benefits like a car, phone, and laptop, accommodation, and promises to spend money on her and provide lots of benefits. He describes himself as having an athletic build, being white, heavily tattooed with brown hair and eyes, not drinking, smoking or using drugs, liking the outdoors and sports, being 175cm tall, "WELL Endowed", owning property, being successful and wealthy, independent, and loving cars and bikes. The advertisement excludes former partners, states all reasonable offers will be considered, and mentions Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact Rich.

FA chairman Greg Dyke seeks to increase home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and redefine 'home-grown' as training three years in England before age 18 instead of before 21, facing Premier League opposition; five former England managers—Taylor, Hoddle, Keegan, Eriksson, and McClaren—support these changes via a letter warning that blocking them risks England falling further behind internationally, noting only 36.8% of Premier League starters are England-eligible and the talent pool is shrinking, though they acknowledge encouraging signs with young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane who need more opportunity.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby daughter, and Ross Poldark is depicted as deeply devoted to her, stating she makes him a better man. However, the show faces criticism for an unrealistic pregnancy timeline, where Demelza progresses from barely showing to eight months pregnant and then giving birth within the span of the latest episode, with fans noticing similar rapid pregnancies for other characters like Elizabeth. This accelerated timeline has prompted social media reactions, such as a fan quipping that pregnancy in Poldark times results in birth within ten minutes.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his players to remain focused solely on their own performances and ignore relegation rivals after back-to-back wins, including Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner at West Brom, lifted them off the bottom of the table and to within three points of safety; Pearson emphasized their survival chances remain in their own hands if they concentrate on their remaining games, warning against distraction from other teams' results or becoming overly optimistic despite their recent improvement.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest recorded mammal migration of nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassing a previous humpback whale record of 10,190 miles; her journey, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, revealed she visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, surprising lead researcher Bruce Mate and suggesting she might be an eastern gray whale despite being initially classified as an endangered western gray whale, which could indicate some western whales are actually eastern grays and necessitate further genetic study as the western population is believed to be only 150 individuals.

Residents on Hokkaido Island, Japan, near Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula, discovered a new stretch of coastline overnight after approximately 1,000-1,640 feet of seabed rose up to 50 feet above sea level. Geologists attribute this emergence to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which forced a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area upwards. Measuring roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, the landmass rose 30-50 feet high and was completely unexpected, as residents reported no tremors or sounds. Authorities confirmed the event was a landslide unrelated to the recent Nepal earthquake and do not expect the land to expand further, with marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins still visible on the exposed surface.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors about leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer and reiterated his love for the club, despite a recent falling-out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea. He insists he is genuinely happy at PSG, loves the club, city, and teammates, sees no reason to leave, and wants to sign a new contract, accepting that playing time is the coach's decision. However, PSG's continued links to Barcelona star Dani Alves raise uncertainty about van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez has informed Juventus he wishes to terminate his contract, which expires in 2016, this summer to return to Boca Juniors, his first club where he started in 1996. Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to sealing a deal but stressed Tevez must first end his agreement with Juventus, who, despite their reluctance to lose their top scorer (17 league goals this season), have accepted his desire to leave and begun identifying replacements. Argentina manager Tata Martino stated Tevez's potential move would not affect his international future and that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great teams.

Bayern Munich dominated Porto with a 6-1 victory at the Allianz Arena, overturning Porto's 3-1 first-leg lead to advance to the Champions League semi-finals; during the emotionally charged match, manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his left trouser leg, exposing his underwear, and afterwards joked about needing new trousers for the next game.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon; collisions involved three vehicles, with a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital for chest/shoulder injuries and chest pain respectively, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. The remaining six people, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment, while a man suffered hand lacerations and two females were uninjured; emergency crews freed one trapped person using hydraulic gear, and helicopters airlifted multiple patients, leading to highway closure south of Fernvale for several hours with diversions in place.

Arsenal, in second place, host Premier League leaders Chelsea at 4pm on Sunday, with playmaker Mesut Ozil excitedly counting down the minutes using his new Apple Watch, showcased on Instagram where he compared it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to start for the Gunners, who trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. Arsenal's position is boosted by Jack Wilshere's return from injury; he was on the bench for their FA Cup semi-final win after five months out. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere, the England international, is Arsenal's future with his quality and ability to link play but expressed significant doubt about his potential to stay fit over a full season, likening his injury concerns to those of former player Abou Diaby.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed referee for the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford, though he has sent off players from both teams this season: City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match and United players Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw in separate Premier League games. Despite a history of controversy, Clattenburg is regarded as a leading Premier League referee alongside Michael Oliver. The match carries added significance as United recently moved one point above City in the standings, with United on a five-game winning streak while City has struggled since the turn of the year. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon would resign parliament after being forced to quit the Labor Party over domestic violence accusations and withholding his criminal history, calling this belief 'a little black puppet on a string'; Gordon instead remained as an independent, throwing the government's razor-thin majority into chaos, while Katter defended his racially charged terminology based on his own Lebanese heritage and past experiences with racism, sparking social media criticism despite his assertion he was calling out racial attitudes, and cited past federal independents like Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of MPs becoming puppets for government but vowed Gordon would not.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois born with cerebral palsy who has faced bullying and stares, creates dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others, aiming to show that while she does things differently, she is fundamentally the same as everyone else and should not be judged or defined solely by her disability; fueled by the desire to turn negativity into positivity, her videos have led her to motivational speaking at local schools, demonstrating her abilities to drive, attend college, and defy initial doctors' predictions that she might never walk.

Orlando City has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who endured a difficult loan spell at Real Madrid, primarily due to their large Latin-American fanbase, though eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan are also keen, with United willing to sell for around £8million; separately, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial offer, and several European clubs including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord have expressed interest in the midfielder.

At least three suspects poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire at a South Los Angeles 76 gas station around 12:15am on Saturday following an argument and an attempted carjacking at gunpoint; the driver fled while two passengers were inside, but no one was injured, though the car was completely destroyed, and the incident is being investigated as arson with suspects still at large using surveillance video.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license to the state Board of Chiropractic after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients; his agreement requires proof that the circumstances of the license revocation no longer exist before he can reapply, which he cannot do for at least 10 years, and includes his practice of advising patients to stop medication he prescribed, despite receiving perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings from three respondents on HealthGrades.com.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a US RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland; the US deemed the Russian pilot's actions "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed close proximity. Russia claimed the US plane was flying toward its border with its transponder off, while the US declared that claim false. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia regarding this incident, similar to a complaint filed last year after another dangerous close pass involving an RC-135U and an SU-27 over the Sea of Okhotsk. Such encounters between Russian and US aircraft are common in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside his car, was stolen overnight from the Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot in Salt Lake City just days before President Obama's March visit; thieves broke the rear passenger window, likely used a rope tied to another vehicle to forcefully rip the case free, also taking the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing/tools (some items recovered nearby), though the rifle remains missing; police found skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken case handle, entered the rifle's serial number into a national database, and noted the hotel lacks surveillance cameras, while the Secret Service was notified but wouldn't comment on security changes, and police are unsure if the agent was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, by allegedly stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa showed evidence of a declining mental state before and during the attack, attributing it to compromised brain function from dementia combined with alcohol abuse, leading to confusion; supporting evidence included fluctuating mood during triple-0 calls and a trail of faeces. While the prosecution suggested Costa feigned memory issues, Professor Mullen believes dementia was likely developing in the lead-up, and Costa's unstable mental state is critical as a proven condition could result in a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley taking a 10th-minute penalty instead of regular taker Leighton Baines, who boasts 15 goals from 16 Premier League attempts, after Barkley's effort was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton; Martinez stated Barkley showed responsibility taking the kick and reiterated his policy of allowing several players to take penalties depending on their confidence, recalling a previous incident where Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed, though this miss proved inconsequential as Mirallas scored the only goal for a 1-0 win.

Two passengers were found dead on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in Puerto Rico, with the cruise line indicating the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The discovery was made by cleaning staff at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday after they knocked on the cabin door; the cabin was immediately secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. Holland America Line stated it is fully cooperating with the ongoing investigation, which will determine the official cause. The ship had departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was currently docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, began his tenure as Curacao coach with a successful 2018 World Cup CONCACAF qualifying campaign, as the team advanced to the second round by defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 second-leg draw, having won the first leg 2-1; Curacao secured progress when Charlton Vicento scored an 87th-minute goal as a substitute, setting up a tie against Cuba on June 8 and 16, with Kluivert, who has maternal ties to Curacao, having previously played and coached at World Cups.

Esteban Cambiasso, despite winning all major European competitions including 15 trophies at Inter Milan and titles with River Plate and Real Madrid, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as significant as winning a trophy, stating "it's like another cup" for him. Leicester currently sits seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with only eight games remaining, having not won a game since January, but Cambiasso refuses to give up, believing they have the ability to avoid relegation and survival is their primary objective this season. Signed last summer on a one-year deal, he has become a key player for the Foxes and, while happy in the East Midlands with his family and open to extending his stay, remains focused on securing crucial points to preserve their Premier League status.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, faces being banned from seeing her two young children by their grandmother, Debbie, who has raised them since infancy due to Gemma's refusal to stop drinking, partying, and using the legal high MKat. Debbie, who took custody after social services threatened intervention, accuses Gemma of stealing an iPad from one child to fund her lifestyle and stealing from her in the past; Gemma denies the iPad theft but admits past thefts. Debbie states Gemma has been irresponsible since her teens, giving up parenting shortly after each birth, prioritizing parties over her children, and showing no commitment; the children now call Debbie "mum." Debbie, feeling unsupported and unable to trust Gemma around the children or their possessions, plans to ban her contact unless she stops the destructive behavior.

Eden Hazard scored for Chelsea against Manchester United after John Terry's strong challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao near the halfway line sent the Colombian striker to the ground, leading to a loose ball collected by Cesc Fabregas, who passed to Oscar before his back-heel released Hazard to score; however, Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness unanimously agreed during half-time analysis that Terry's tackle, which included an elbow to Falcao's back, was a foul that should have halted play, despite acknowledging the goal's quality and differing views on Falcao's ability to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway after a rear tire blew out; Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and driver were safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames. Michael Barnett captured video of the fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas but stopped filming as he approached, uncertain if anyone was hurt. Scott later posted photos of the charred bus on Instagram, noting her Bible survived the destruction of the back lounge's contents and thanking God for their safety; the band's other members were not on board at the time. Lady Antebellum is still set to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, that Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers that use satellites covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light via semiconductors, and beam the energy back to Earth to boost the output of solar panels, potentially making solar power viable in places like Scotland and enabling quick power restoration in disaster areas; successful initial trials occurred in Scotland, with plans to move to Portugal, though Quarterman acknowledges possible concerns about satellite control. These lasers are not powerful enough to act like weapons or harm wildlife, unlike the sci-fi depictions, and are distinct from a separate Japanese proposal using International Space Station lasers to clear small space debris by pushing it into the atmosphere to burn up, which also lacks weapon power.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, went missing from a psychiatric hospital near Hook, Hampshire at 6.15pm on Tuesday after vanishing from the facility where he was detained under the Mental Health Act. Convicted last August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and admitting ten unrelated offences of possessing indecent images of children, Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and autism and is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair and possibly having shaved off his beard, has sparked a police manhunt as officers urgently seek information on his whereabouts due to the risk he poses.

V. Stiviano was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts, including luxury cars and a duplex, she received from Donald Sterling after Sterling's wife, Shelly, successfully sued her, claiming the gifts were bought with the couple's money; Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate, but Shelly Sterling's lawyer called it a victory setting a precedent for injured spouses. This follows Donald Sterling's loss of his NBA team the previous year due to racist remarks he made to Stiviano, captured in an audio recording where he chastised her for posting pictures with African-Americans like Magic Johnson, leading NBA Commissioner Adam Silver to ban him from the league, fine him $2.5 million, and terminate his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal's recent transfer dealings, urging his former club to sign four players—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to win the Premier League; he questioned whether Olivier Giroud, despite scoring 14 goals, is sufficient as first-choice striker for a title challenge and pointed to Chelsea's success after buying players like Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as evidence such investment is necessary, stating Arsenal must add top-quality competition to their squad.

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child; she described being scared for future relationships, confusion during childhood abuse not knowing it was wrong, staying silent until learning he was caught, subsequent depression, self-harm, hospitalization for suicide attempts, fear of people finding out, and worry that Van Ryn's custody release and his actions will permanently affect her relationships with men, while Van Ryn sat calmly in the dock without looking at her during her statement.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury sustained during a Champions League match against Bayern Munich in March 2014, which kept him out for over a year after previously impressing for the Gunners. He has now played two full 90-minute matches for Arsenal's Under-21s, including a recent game against Reading, and states he is feeling "better and better," having overcome his injury worries and looking forward to the next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant from Reading working for Liam Gallagher's clothing brand, died after accidentally falling 70ft from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing a taxi at night to avoid paying the fare; he had been drinking in Cardiff, couldn't afford the full journey with friends, planned to dodge the payment by pretending to use an ATM, ran off separated from his friends in pitch darkness, leapt over a fence near the disused Northern Promenade, and became disoriented, unaware of the cliff's danger until he plunged, with his body discovered the next morning by a dog walker, leading the coroner to record a verdict of accidental death.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays received no compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the crisis and managers receiving up to £3,500 in bonuses; ministers refused a blanket refund for those who paid extra for rushed passports or missed trips, resulting in only 2,191 compensation applications being approved between April and January, totaling £203,066, while a government database failure obscured rejection numbers and ministers rejected compensation demands citing "precedent" concerns, exemplified by cases like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham who lost £1,500 on a missed trip to Morocco despite applying ten weeks early and paying for upgrades.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale, having remained untouched for over 80 years, preserving original features like stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, original kitchen cupboards and sink, brick open-face fireplace, and vintage food tins on a shelf; this three-bedroom semi-detached collector's paradise, double glazed but potentially costly to renovate, is guided at £200,000-£250,000 and will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith for the 49ers but became the starter during the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion; he remained the starter for the rest of that season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before later moving to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile-long freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London and around Colchester, Essex, attending Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon; they formed Blur, whose debut album "Leisure" (1991) received mixed reviews, while drawing influences from alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Blur released their self-titled album in 2001 to worldwide success. His debut solo studio album "Everyday Robots" (28 April 2014), co-produced by Richard Russell, featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and sampled rants by Lord Buckley.

Mogadishu, known locally as Hamar and also referred to as Muqdisho or مقديشو, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, serving as the location for the country's important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP), Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two adaptations titled "Shooter": a 2007 film and a TV series. The film stars Mark Wahlberg as Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit. The TV series features Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action to stop a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that originally aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—committed by his followers at his instruction; he also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald Shea, and after being charged with these crimes, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his acting career with a brief TV appearance in Little House on the Prairie directed by his father, Leo Penn, before making his film debut in Taps (1981). He gained critical attention for diverse roles in the 1980s including Fast Times at Ridgemont High and crime dramas like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn achieved prominence as a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Berlin Film Festival Best Actor Award, and received subsequent Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). He won the Academy Award for Best Actor twice, for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC, was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time, living from 27 August 1908 to 25 February 2001. Following his retirement, he retained a pre-eminent position in cricket for three decades by acting as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held multiple high-level executive positions in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007); he began his career drumming for Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha, and as of 2016 plays drums in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

The multi-camera series "The Millers" aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running for 34 episodes over two seasons before being cancelled by CBS on November 14, 2014, just four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was an American Democrat who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995 after gaining national attention as Texas state treasurer with a keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention; she was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush and was the state's second female governor, noted for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. Separately, Ann Richards (1935–1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011 independently.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona, while Janet Leigh, whose full name was Jeanette Helen Morrison and who lived from July 6, 1927, to October 3, 2004, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios (24 July 1783 - 17 December 1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have vanished under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional football career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback during the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion; Kaepernick then led the team to Super Bowl XLVII, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In the 2013 season, his first full year as starter, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship game, resulting in a loss to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual marketing communication employing an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea, differentiated from personal selling by its nonpersonal nature, and communicated through various mass media including old media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, or direct mail, and new media such as search results, blogs, websites, or text messages.
Private Lives is both a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, (1894-1986) was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle, an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in 384 BC in Stagira, Chalkidice, joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and remained until approximately thirty-seven years old (c. 347 BC); shortly after Plato's death, he left Athens and, at Philip II of Macedon's request, tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC, dying in 322 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur who invented the guitar pedal drum machine called the BeatBuddy and currently serves as CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons after being selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft following high school and college championships; he won a championship and NBA Finals MVP as a rookie and added four more titles in the 1980s. He retired after player protests, returned briefly in 1996 at age 36 for 32 games, then retired permanently. Later named one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine in 2009, he has numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, consisting of lead vocalist and guitarist Jack Black and lead guitarist and vocalist Kyle Gass. The band has released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They first gained popularity in 1997 starring in their eponymous television series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625, with Scotland and England remaining separate sovereign states under his personal union, each possessing their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. Derek Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film, in 2013.

Lady Gaga's song "Bad Romance" is from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster; it was showcased at Paris Fashion Week after a demo leak, became a global chart-topping hit, and sold 12 million copies, making it one of the best-selling singles ever; the passage also notes an unrelated 2011 independent drama film titled Bad Romance (Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, encompassing franchises like Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, along with other hits such as Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank Sr. is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., is a current British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, previously won the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016, and as of May 2017 was ranked the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth best middleweight by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News, and his younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, is an Australian-British-American businessman serving as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
