In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/model in Israel, trailing behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with the majority of her income deriving from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, informally known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically detected by a radiographic examination, commonly referred to as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large region in south Wales rich in coal deposits, particularly concentrated within the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, originally known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when first organized in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother upon her eldest son Edward's accession in 1936 after George's death, but he abdicated later that year to marry Wallis Simpson; she then supported her second son Albert, who succeeded as George VI until his death in 1952, and she died the following year during her granddaughter Elizabeth II's reign before Elizabeth's coronation.
Poseidon is a film that grossed $181,674,817 at the worldwide box office, produced on a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented in 1996, and Omar Epps and Joe Morton each hold the record for the most wins with three awards.

Human trafficking involves trading humans primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) reports forced labor generated an estimated $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014, with exploitation breakdowns showing 14.2 million people (68%) in labor exploitation, 4.5 million (22%) sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) in state-imposed forced labor.
The 2011 film Rio had a sequel titled Rio 2, which was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I (Franz Stefan, 1708-1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife held real power, while Francis I (François Ier, 1494-1547) was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death and known by nicknames like "Francis of the Large Nose" and the "Knight-King" for his wars against his rival Charles V, King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor; after unsuccessful conflicts, Francis I of France formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent, and the passage specifically mentions the Italian War of 1536-1538 between him and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU), commonly called Beida in Chinese, is a major research university in Beijing and a C9 League member, established in 1898 as China's first modern national university (Imperial University of Peking) to replace the ancient Imperial Academy, also serving as the initial highest education administration, and is consistently ranked as mainland China's top higher learning institution.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and his distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant threats to humans, including endangering food security through decreasing crop yields and forcing the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
The 2008 Australian-American-British film Australia is a romantic historical adventure drama directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices like food-making and craft-making, including oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films noted for being both informative and entertaining, while also producing training films and training combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was promptly adapted into a film and later a television series. James Jones (basketball player) achieved Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors in high school, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, won three NBA championships (two with the Heat, one with the Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals for seven consecutive years with LeBron James in 2017, finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season, and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process used for generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, which became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor renowned for portraying the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, marking the longest tenure in the role, and for his narration of the comedy series Little Britain; beyond these, he has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and other television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located within the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site hosts a cleanup project, the commercial Columbia Generating Station nuclear power plant, and scientific research centers including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official whose primary responsibility is acting as spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly concerning the President, senior executives, and policies. Appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the president, the position does not require U.S. Senate confirmation. Despite not being a Cabinet post, it is a very prominent role due to the frequent media briefings provided to inform the public.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State" due to the bluegrass in its pastures resulting from fertile soil, features the central Bluegrass Region containing Louisville and Lexington, and is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal production, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, with Kelly Preston also having starred in the films The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert (pronounced [ˈkɛʃə_roʊz_ˈsɛbərt]), born March 1, 1987, and formerly stylized as Ke$ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually pay-per-view; pressured by WWF's 1987 Survivor Series exclusivity demand, it became the first NWA pay-per-view that year. The 1985 event aired live on closed-circuit TV. In 2014, WWE Network included Starrcades from 1983-1986 in its pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA due to violent matches like the "I Quit" bout between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. Starrcade 1997 was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view iteration.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian national working as a stunt and action choreographer and film director within the Bollywood film industry.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for that service and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

The passage describes three distinct entities: "Excuse My French" as the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana, "Excuse My French" as a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama based on his experiences at a public school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia, and Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (born 22 October 1983), known professionally as Plan B or Ben Drew, a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk is a disk storage medium consisting of a thin and flexible magnetic storage disk sealed within a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, followed by a bloody civil war from 1960 to 1996 fought between a US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military perpetrated genocidal massacres of the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects, and outside medicine they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, following its sixth season which concluded as cable's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is a fictional character and the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, portrayed by Matthew Fox. Lost, an American television drama series, aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with the first season attracting an estimated average of 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor who has preferred dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films including The Lincoln Lawyer (2011), Bernie (2011), Killer Joe (2011), The Paperboy (2012), Mud (2012), Magic Mike (2012), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Dallas Buyers Club (2013), Interstellar (2014), The Sea of Trees (2016), and Free State of Jones (2016); the 2012 film Mud specifically stars McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is primarily recognized as a writer, known for his books including *Deep Blues*; his extensive music journalism for publications like the *New York Times* and *Rolling Stone* magazine; his role as a producer of blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film *Deep Blues*; and his past activity as a clarinet player in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941; Gutzon had created the design and led the project from 1927 to 1941 with Lincoln's assistance, and Lincoln assumed leadership of the construction upon his father's death.

The film "Underdog" was directed by Frederik Du Chau, written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams, and features a live-action cast including Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, alongside voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The TV series "The 100" follows a group of teens—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse; the series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (a council member on the Ark), and Thelonious Jaha (the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a humanitarian aid project that encountered financial problems due to its pioneering nature, but is recognized as highly successful and influential for generating significant awareness and considerable funds, while also providing valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent projects, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers, widely credited with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas at the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois; these debates, a series of seven between Republican candidate Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Douglas, drew large crowds from neighboring states at Freeport, Quincy, and Alton due to the monumental national importance of slavery.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author of gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica who began her professional writing career in California with the 1976 publication of *Interview with the Vampire* and wrote sequels starting in the 1980s, facing mixed reactions to her early works before gaining more popularity with critics and readers during that decade; she was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 recorded at the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey, and its population at the beginning of the twentieth century consisted mostly of European immigrants; a city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, directed by Paul Schrader, which was critically derided and described as an original work.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven debates held in seven towns across Illinois between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican U.S. Senate candidate, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Senator, contesting for the Illinois Senate seat.

Homer is the name ascribed by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and Odyssey, central works of ancient Greek literature, while The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, born April 8, 1974, and he was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band consisting of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007), having started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage in August 1991. As of 2016, he played in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of rapper Zac de la Rocha, bassist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records; in 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Flaked was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly during two separate periods (1784-1785 and 1798-1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), was chosen as a U.S. Senator from the State of New York (1791-1797), and reached the highest point of his career as vice president.

Soyuz was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight unmanned test flights followed by the first nineteen manned launches. Named "Union" referencing the Soviet Union, the spacecraft series was designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s and remains in service. It succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built for the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Growing tensions over the band's direction led to Zack de la Rocha quitting Rage Against the Machine, causing the band's breakup; de la Rocha began a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella, and their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, and it is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous in Asia. It is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the world's highest economic growth rates and achieved the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011, while remaining one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who performed two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India; his execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became a popular folk hero after his death.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's film "Dangal," which is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari and centered on a wrestling competition.

James VI and I ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625, born 19 June 1566; although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, he ruled both in personal union, actively advocating for a single parliament for both kingdoms, while facing significant difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress born on December 26, 1970, who gained recognition as an original core cast member of the soap opera Shortland Street and is known for roles including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and Bea Smith in the prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years until leaving in 2016; her other work includes the 2009 film Separation City and the Australian series Rake.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2, with Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser specifically noted as a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Lady Gaga's album Artpop received mixed critical reviews but achieved commercial success by debuting at number one on the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming her second consecutive US number-one album, selling 757,000 copies total in the US, and ranking as the ninth best-selling album of 2013 globally with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

John Frusciante was featured on the Red Hot Chili Peppers' album "Stadium Arcadium," released in 2006, which was the group's fifth and final album with him and also marked his last contribution before he confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism and remains a controversial figure, lauded as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians despite ongoing arguments over her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who has established himself as a writer, creating weekly columns on diverse topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, besides performing acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre. It is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, and Valencia is its namesake capital and the nation's third largest city and metropolitan area.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series Make It or Break It was announced to have ended on April 26, 2012, with the third season being the final one, and its series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics combining linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering, enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. Its applications include voice user interfaces like voice dialing, call routing, domotic appliance control, content search, simple data entry, structured document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. Advances in the field are driven by the global adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players, including Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, originally called the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group including Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and served as its chairman beginning in 1970.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which featured Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the lead at 16 under par after rounds of 67 and 66 respectively, while McIlroy, tied with Thailand's Aphibarnrat at 15 under, carded his third consecutive 67 despite dropping shots early and showing frustration; the four-time major winner, recovering from a July ankle ligament rupture that sidelined him before a PGA Championship defense and FedEx Cup participation, aims for his first title since May and leads the Race to Dubai, significantly ahead of Danny Willett with three events left, as overnight leaders Chris Wood and Richard Bland dropped to fifth and seventh.

Sheikh Ali Salman demands the Bahraini government show willingness for concrete solutions in national dialogue, specifically requesting Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, a reformist, represent the royal family, while hardliners led by the long-serving Prime Minister oppose concessions, fearing further demands; despite young protesters losing faith in opposition parties due to government violence, Salman insists dialogue is necessary and highlights a failed 2011 seven-point agreement with the crown prince before GCC troops intervened; he expresses hope US Secretary of State John Kerry will pressure Bahrain on human rights and democracy, criticizes the UK government for only privately urging reform, and insists al-Wefaq will continue calling for peaceful protests and the release of thirteen imprisoned opposition leaders, stating their exclusion guarantees dialogue failure.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home following a prolonged illness, with a private funeral planned and a memorial service to follow. He was a highly influential figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it globally for 30 years, producing over 200 recordings including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His renowned 1980 Handel's Messiah recording is considered one of the greatest ever. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held prominent academic positions, including at Harvard and Cambridge University, and served as artistic director for the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. Tributes highlighted his extraordinary generosity, role as a founder of historically informed performance, significant legacy for the AAM, immense intellect, and his impact on training leading musicians globally.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland dropped to 57 in the year ending March 2016, down five from the previous year, marking the lowest annual figure since 1976 and half the number recorded nine years prior, with only one 2015-16 case unresolved as of March 31, 2016; sharp instruments, primarily knives, were the most common method, accounting for 51% (29 cases, including 26 involving knives), while 31% of the accused were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted the long-term decline in violent crime but stressed continued efforts through education and enforcement to prevent further loss of life, address alcohol misuse, and challenge casual violence. However, Scottish Labour's Claire Baker welcomed the downward trend but urged caution, noting past upward revisions of homicide figures and highlighting a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault alongside sexual crime reaching a 45-year high; the initial 2014-15 figure of 59 victims was later revised to 62.

Bournemouth suffered a 2-1 defeat against Sunderland, the first loss Sunderland inflicted in the Premier League this season, with Dan Gosling's opening goal ending Bournemouth's three-game goal drought; manager Eddie Howe dismissed confidence issues, referencing their six goals against Hull earlier, and expressed frustration at failing to score despite creating numerous chances, which he felt were sufficient to win multiple games, after Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty put Sunderland ahead, leaving Bournemouth unable to find an equaliser even after Steven Pienaar's red card reduced Sunderland to ten men.

Mr. Abbott asserted that stopping migrant boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea, citing Australia's policy of detaining boat migrants and sending them to offshore camps for eventual resettlement elsewhere; the New York Times editorial condemned this "ruthlessly effective" policy as "brutal," "inhumane," "of dubious legality," and contrary to Australia's welcoming traditions, urging European leaders not to adopt it. While Abbott acknowledged the "very sad" image of drowned Syrian boy Alan Kurdi, he reiterated that stopping boats stops drownings. Separately, Abbott angered Jewish groups by claiming IS, which many migrants flee, is worse than the Nazis because it "boasts about its evil" unlike the Nazis who "had a sufficient sense of shame to try to hide it"; Jewish leader Robert Goot called this "injudicious," distinguishing IS terrorism from the Nazis' systematic state genocide and purpose-built death camps. Abbott later defended his comments, stating he stands by them but is not "in the business of ranking evil."

The United States suspended bilateral talks with Russia over Syria, blaming Moscow and the Syrian government for intensified attacks on civilians in Aleppo, including strikes on hospitals and a humanitarian convoy, and for failing to uphold the ceasefire agreement; Russia regretted the US decision, accusing Washington of not fulfilling its own commitments to improve Aleppo's humanitarian situation and attempting to shift blame for the truce's collapse, while denying responsibility for the convoy attack; since the truce lapsed, heavy government bombardment of Aleppo has killed hundreds, trapped 250,000 people in the east, and led to the US recalling personnel for a joint implementation center, though counter-terrorism discussions will continue.

A Policy Exchange report, backed by Downing Street, proposes selling high-value social homes (defined as above the regional average property value, constituting 21.8% of the UK total stock) when vacant, aiming to raise £4.5bn annually after debt repayment to fund a major social housebuilding programme creating 80,000 to 170,000 new homes and potentially reducing the 1.8 million-person waiting list by 500,000; however, Labour and critics strongly oppose the plan, arguing it would displace low-income families, create segregated communities, and break up mixed neighbourhoods, instead suggesting taxing bank bonuses to build affordable homes, while the Housing Minister defends government reforms and existing powers for councils to implement such sales.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, the center of a measles outbreak with 942 cases, though an initial examination could not confirm measles as the primary cause of death, prompting an inquest. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospitalization. His mother stated he had recently been treated for asthma, developed a rash head-to-foot but not on his arms, saw an out-of-hours GP on April 17th, and was found dead the next morning. Public Health Wales confirmed his measles diagnosis via lab tests but needs further testing to determine the death cause. The family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, aged 54 of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16, reported to have occurred in 2001, and is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley, both on strong unbeaten runs in the National League, drew 1-1; Guiseley took a 15th-minute lead against the run of play when a throw-in reached James Hurst, who squared to Jake Lawlor to slot into an empty net, while Gateshead levelled on 62 minutes when a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah allowed Wes York to curl a shot into the top-right corner from the edge of the box, with Liam Hogan blocking an effort and Jonny Maxted making a key save before the equaliser.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity instead of pursuing a delayed new stadium at Ashton Vale; majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed this at a shareholder meeting, following Bristol City Council's approval in November, stating they will sign a section 106 agreement shortly and await a six-week judicial review period, aiming to begin redevelopment in May if no review is lodged by March.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months near Poulton-le-Fylde, and will consult with authorities and experts for weeks using data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding to resume. The BGS stated both tremors shared a similar location and mechanism near the Preese Hall drill site, noting that processes injecting pressurised water underground, like fracking, can cause earthquakes, and is monitoring the activity as a precaution. While fracking is controversial in the US over environmental issues like flammable tap water, a UK parliamentary committee argued these could be overcome by tight regulation and good industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud but cleared of two others at Liverpool Crown Court. The conviction stemmed from an April 2015 incident where he played with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes, giving the impression he was collecting funds for the charity, according to Sgt Chris Gaynor. Carpenter defended himself, stating he was simply busking, the banner was a tribute to victims, and Kenneth Derbyshire, the campaign chairman, had granted permission to display the banner but explicitly forbade using it to collect money. Carpenter, a familiar busker at Anfield on matchdays known to the campaign, will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (capitalizing on QPR keeper Alex Smithies' miscued clearance), and Tom Lawrence (finishing Cole Skuse's saved shot). Rangers offered little attack, only hitting the post late via Sandro's header, while Ipswich missed several chances to extend their lead. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy cited Smithies' error as decisive but praised Luke Varney's performance, noting the win lifted Ipswich to 14th above 15th-placed QPR. QPR boss Ian Holloway blamed the second goal calamity for a poor performance, calling for greater mental toughness from his team.

Wells, aged 23, impressed in the T20 Blast last season by scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he stated the club is going in the right direction with an exciting elite performance environment created by the coaches that makes players want to be part of it.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12, with coach Churcher highlighting Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams for leading the team, particularly praising their front row for making over 70 tackles; the team faces seven teams below them plus league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games, and while Churcher views the Chinnor performance as emotionally dogged but incomplete, he stresses the need to build on the win to avoid wasting it.

Police allege 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on March 14th, which also involved robbery and ransacking; he was arrested at a Kolkata railway station, marking the sixth arrest in the case where eight suspects are identified and two remain untraced, following a tip-off he was returning from Bangladesh after being identified via CCTV and named by five previously arrested suspects, and sparking nationwide outrage and protests.

This interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explains factors influencing consumer purchasing changes in the UK, including the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports, while also exploring shifts in the ownership and ranking of major UK brands; it may not function on older browsers (with a non-interactive alternative available), is best viewed full screen, and provides supplementary links on Chinese brand ownership, freezing tips, brand rankings, and the museum.

Two separate scams targeted elderly women: a 71-year-old in Sandyhills was tricked on September 15 by a fake BT caller, and a woman in Stranraer lost money seven days later after giving remote computer access to someone claiming to be from BT technical support about internet problems. Police PC Siobhan Pellett warned these scams frighteningly easily gain computer access and involve substantial sums of stolen money, urging extreme caution with cold calls requesting remote access and stressing that banking details or account numbers should never be given over the phone, as legitimate institutions never request this information.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has joined third-placed Championship side Featherstone Rovers on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions; he will manage their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a "fantastic coach," highlighting his remarkable work under difficult circumstances at Swinton. Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford over a 16-year career, has been succeeded at Swinton by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT on Sunday for a rider found unconscious on wet sand suffering head injuries and extreme cold; the rider was treated at the scene before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite-based global flight tracking, enabling real-time monitoring worldwide by allowing satellites to receive aircraft ADS-B transmissions. This decision, made at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC) organised by the ITU, addresses weaknesses exposed by the 2014 disappearance of MH370, which vanished over 70% of airspace not covered by ground-based radar. The move follows Malaysia's urgent request for new tracking methods after the plane, en route to Beijing, was lost; debris found on Reunion Island was later confirmed as part of MH370. The ITU Secretary-General stated the agency responded quickly to global demands, and the UN's aviation arm, ICAO, has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking standards requiring position reports every 15 minutes or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at 18 living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland; Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested following an FBI tip received on October 30th triggered by Julian's college application issues, with the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirming his identity. Julian's mother has been notified, while Bobby Hernandez is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail, charged with tampering with records to obtain a 2012 Ohio driver's license, and was long suspected by authorities since he fled with Julian in August 2002 after claiming to take him to pre-school.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a blaze on March 2 reduced train services and caused delays; the Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and later revoked its environmental permit, effective August 7 subject to appeal, following concerns raised jointly by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) and the EA about potential impacts, though GMFRS stated the site operators, Asset and Land Group, had been broadly compliant during their nine visits in the last year, and the fire's cause remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia introduced two bills directly linked to the Ukraine crisis, both targeting Crimea due to its strong separatist and pro-Russian sentiment. The first proposes amending Russian law to allow annexing territories from a "disintegrating" neighboring state solely based on a local referendum or leader's request, bypassing the current requirement for a signed treaty, with MPs arguing this is necessary to accept territories expressing a clear desire to join Russia, referencing past actions in Georgia. The second bill creates a fast-track process for Ukrainian citizens, especially Russian-speakers, to obtain Russian passports by removing taxes, prior residency, self-sufficiency, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship requirements; it aims to aid those facing a "brown threat" (fascist reference) and allows applications at Russian missions until 1 August, granting citizenship in two months instead of one, a plan announced in Sevastopol and accompanied by visits from Russian MPs and celebrities to Crimea.

McLaren, a historically dominant F1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers' titles, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently struggling, targeting fourth or third grid positions; this slump stems from chassis design issues starting in 2013 compounded by unreliable Honda power units, contrasting sharply with their past Honda partnership success. Their history features cycles of triumph, like the dominant 1988-1991 Senna/Prost era and 1998-1999 Hakkinen wins, and decline, including scandals in 2007 ('Spygate') and 2009 ('Lie-gate') that damaged reputation and results. Despite current difficulties, including consecutive winless seasons since 2012, team leadership under Ron Dennis believes they are arresting the slide, citing strong chassis this year and projected Honda engine improvements for next year, aiming to end Mercedes' dominance and secure future "championships, plural" with two-time champion Fernando Alonso, who returned hoping for a third title.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was found badly injured with gunshot wounds to the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital; three Liverpool men (two aged 29 and one aged 32) arrested in connection remain in police custody. Merseyside Police believe Baker was shot while getting into his car after leaving Phoenix Gym at the market, with suspects waiting outside for about an hour, and they are searching for a silver VW Polo that sped away along routes including Balmoral, Molyneux, and Queens Roads. Detective Chief Inspector Bev Hyland stated that people captured on CCTV near the meat market who have not yet come forward could hold key information to the investigation.

The passage presents five digital ways to celebrate Christmas spiritually: Everyday Church Online offers virtual global services, including Star Wars-themed Christmas sermons called "The Hope Awakens"; Guardians of Ancora, a free Bible-themed game for 8-11-year-olds on mobile platforms, features Christmas quests about finding Jesus's birth; popular viral nativity videos like "The Digital Story of Nativity" (told via social media) and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" (rejected for cinemas as "too religious") retell the story; Next Manga distributes its "Manga Messiah" nativity book as an app/e-book, including to refugees; and churches utilize social media platforms like Twitter to share spiritual thoughts and connect with communities.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares of replacement land; conflicting expert accounts exist on whether the development would damage habitats and plant life, with Natural Resources Wales stating it was difficult to conclude the replacement land was of equal value (though not opposing the development), while developers claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity through habitat enhancements (a claim contested by the Gwent Wildlife Trust); the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers having the final decision.

Novaya Gazeta reported on 1 April that over 100 people suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed, a claim confirmed by the Russian LGBT Network who detailed torture including electric shocks at a prison near Argun; Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, condemning the report as insulting Islam and Chechen dignity, adopting a resolution calling for "retribution" against the instigators, which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a call for violence against journalists, a threat confirmed by the Chechen spiritual leader; Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations and his spokesman claimed no gay people exist in Chechnya; detainees reportedly included influential figures close to Kadyrov; Novaya Gazeta's editor defended their work and vowed to continue reporting amidst the threats and a history of unsolved murders of their reporters; the LGBT Network is aiding escapes and warns of seeking International Criminal Court action if Russian authorities fail to prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, profits significantly by housing multiple single homeless men in one property and claiming housing benefit for each tenant individually, resulting in payouts exceeding the rent passed to private landlords; the charity Fresh Start Housing, also based in the same south London storage unit and founded by Investing Solutions' creator Samir Patel, refers clients from London homeless shelters to the agency, which operates as one of the UK's largest housing benefit recipients, earning substantial annual profits per property—like £11,568 from one house—while tenants report severely unsuitable conditions including lack of heating, rats, and rubbish, though both organizations deny wrongdoing, with Investing Solutions emphasizing rent passed to landlords and Fresh Start stating it has housed hundreds of people, while critics like Crisis condemn the arrangement as a "new low" and Wandsworth Council, which has paid the agency over £2.1 million, asserts it safeguards taxpayer money.

In a warm-up match before Eurobasket qualifiers, Great Britain led for most of the game against Netherlands but were overhauled in the fourth quarter and lost; Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for GB, who now begin their qualifying campaign in Hungary. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the need for consistent effort and was pleased with Gordon's contribution despite GB losing the lead after he hit three consecutive threes in the third quarter, as Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, scored the first 10 points of the fourth and held on for the win despite GB's late comeback.

McGregor submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves in his 154lb fight against Mayweather, after Mayweather stated he would wear them; the NAC rules require 10oz gloves for 154lbs but allow deviations with waivers if justified, prioritizing fighter safety. The NAC will debate McGregor's request publicly on August 16th. NAC Executive Director Bob Bennett, who had approved the fight after studying McGregor's abilities (citing his wins over Nate Diaz, physical advantages, and sparring footage), has since received videos confirming McGregor is prepared. Bennett advised hiring a boxing referee, leading to Joe Cortez joining McGregor's camp; Cortez oversaw sparring sessions involving Paulie Malignaggi, who left the camp after images surfaced of him on the canvas.

Fleet Street, historically the center of British journalism since the first daily newspaper launched there in 1702, reached its peak supplying 85% of the public's information through national papers packed into its half-mile radius, renowned for its journalist-filled pubs, typewriter-filled newsrooms, and printing presses; however, Rupert Murdoch's 1986 move to Wacking triggered its decline as other papers followed, adopting cheaper technology and vacating buildings later repurposed for supermarkets and restaurants, ultimately culminating with the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, marking the departure of its last two journalists, Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff, who reflect on the area's rich history and the end of an iconic era.

J.K. Rowling stated on Twitter that the "decent people" outweighing abusive ones reminded her of the world's size, reaffirming her stance against bullies after her "personal line was crossed" and acknowledging the challenges of being a famous woman online. She faced a Twitter backlash following her £1m donation to the campaign against Scottish independence, mirroring a similar 2008 donation to Labour, and revealed she had been called "a traitor" and blocked abusive users she believed were SNP supporters, refusing to suppress such actions to protect any party's image. However, Rowling also noted she had positive exchanges with other SNP supporters, finding political common ground, and joked about "bringing marshmallows" after a user suggested burning her books. This occurred in the context of the SNP securing 56 of 59 Scottish seats and becoming the UK's third-largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 young people found children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than their wealthier peers for the same crimes and poor youth are five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision, with household poverty identified as a key exacerbating factor for offending even after accounting for other risks; living in poverty also increased violence likelihood for both genders, with boys three times more likely than girls to be violent, and while girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely to be involved in violent crime than affluent girls, the study highlighted a destructive dynamic where poverty increases violence risks and contact with the juvenile justice system inadvertently worsens poverty conditions; a related report noted falling crime rates haven't improved the most deprived areas, with high-crime communities concentrated in areas of chronic health problems and unemployment, though the Scottish government stated Scotland is becoming safer with crime at a 41-year low and emphasized initiatives tackling poverty.

Mr Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway at Kilkee's Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday; Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August following a district court hearing. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged Walsh and two others entered the estate after 01:00 Sunday searching for Haugh, encountered him with another man, and a fight involving weapons (knives and golf clubs) ensued, with other individuals joining; during the altercation, Haugh suffered a stab wound to the back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Gardaí recovered a knife handle and blood-stained blade at the scene.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA for Fermanagh, tweeted in May 2014 falsely alleging that Tom Elliott, now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, had harassed and shot people during his 10-year service in the UDR (1982-1992), from which he has a clear MoD record; Elliott pursued legal action after being alerted to the tweet, leading Flanagan to delete it within an hour; the High Court ordered Flanagan to publicly apologise on Twitter, admitting the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation", and reserved judgement on compensation; Stormont's MLA insurance firm refused indemnity for costs, which Flanagan is challenging separately, and Elliott stated he felt "totally vindicated", disappointed by the 19-month delay but delighted with the result.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff and dating back to 1874, was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year; it has increased sweater production to 9,500 weekly (from 7,500 last year) due to strong demand driven by better-than-expected sales of its new branded range launched in January and growth in its established private label business, serving markets across Europe including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as internationally in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan, with Mr. Hartop attributing the success to dedicated staff and expressing strong optimism for the future.

Brian Wright, 55, denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving after his VW Golf failed to stop at a red light and struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady on duty outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December, causing serious head injuries that now require her to be in residential care; Wright, who claims the setting sun blinded him and caused him to miss the red light while Mrs Blackburn was escorting a woman and child across the road, expressed deep remorse in Luton Crown Court, admitting he struck her and turning her "world upside down," and the trial continues.

NATO is conducting the "Dynamic Mongoose" exercise, where the German submarine U33 simulates an enemy target for 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, aiming to highlight the growing threat and increased patrols from technologically advanced Russian submarines, which are described as the "quietest and most challenging adversary" in the world. The exercise underscores the extreme difficulty of detecting hidden submarines, likened to finding a needle in a haystack, involving surface ship visual scans, sonar monitoring, helicopters, and for the first time, underwater drones offering cheaper, persistent surveillance. Critically, the exercise reveals a significant gap in Britain's defences due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing reliance on allies for aerial reconnaissance when Russian submarines are reported near UK waters, a vulnerability experts warn could allow tracking of the UK's nuclear deterrent and must be addressed in the upcoming defence review, as finding real Russian submarines would be harder than hunting U33.

Violence escalating since July in South Sudan, particularly in southern Equatoria states, has caused 340,000 refugees to flee to Uganda this year, exceeding even Syria's outflow; UN officials warn of potential genocide and ethnic cleansing, with daily accounts of killing, rape, and targeting along ethnic lines, especially Equatorians by Dinka forces, causing mass displacement; Uganda provides refugees land plots and aid but struggles with the scale, especially water supply, as international pressure is urged to stop the "massacre of civilians" amid stories of deep trauma and loss from survivors.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He turned professional in 2013 after quitting football two years prior, having played for Norwich and Peterborough. From his nine fights, he has eight wins and one draw. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital, part of a £330m NHS investment for England, will cost £33m funded by the coalition government, NHS Somerset, and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, replacing the outdated 1813 building; it will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners, aiming for completion by autumn 2014 on land at Bowers Lane pending planning permission, with Matron Sue Taylor citing the current facility's poor condition and Dr. Donal Hynes highlighting its potential for integrated care, while three other Somerset community hospitals have been replaced in the last five years and work has begun on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city center, while either in or close to a black Mercedes car he was driving; police called around 13:35 GMT found him with a chest wound, he was taken to Northern General Hospital but died, residents stated he belonged to a family nearby gathered for a celebration, relatives tried to help after hearing the shot, and this follows recent shootings elsewhere in Sheffield (Shiregreen, Southey Green, High Green) though previous incidents were not near Upperthorpe.

Pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct cyber warfare including DDoS attacks against rebel websites, hacking payment systems, monitoring CCTV in separatist areas, hijacking printers for messages, and claimed hacking Russian servers; group Inform Napalm analyzed their leaked data finding evidence of Russian soldiers in Ukraine. Opposing them is anti-Western Cyber Berkut, hacking Ukrainian government sites, alleging documents from Biden's visit, manipulating billboards with graphic content, claiming to disrupt elections and leak defense data, and spreading unverified claims like Ukrainian officials admitting to downing MH17. Russian group Anonymous International (Shaltay Boltay) publishes leaked Kremlin documents, though sourcing is unclear; their releases include a Russian fighter's letter questioning separatist support and emails from rebel commander Strelkov, and their website is blocked in Russia.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during farewell speeches by veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, both standing down ahead of the May 5th election alongside Marwick and Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie; Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is "diverse, not divided," praised the parliament's journey towards greater responsibility, welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill but insisted it failed unionist referendum pledges, and joked about competing events and wishing opponents luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm"; McNeil, serving since 1999, warned Holyrood must learn committee lessons from Westminster to ensure accountability and scrutiny, lamenting the need to look south for governance improvements; Goldie humorously noted she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation"; Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care, calling on pensioners, families, and friends to share their experiences to inform recommendations for providers and public bodies; the review will assess physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, aiming to highlight good care and the impact of poor care, with the commissioner noting unacceptable variations across Wales during her travels and correspondence; her team will consult providers and public bodies, but Care Forum Wales supports the review's goals while criticizing the exclusion of providers and those with direct care home experience from the advisory panel, viewing it as a missed opportunity for partnership.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite an £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies animal feed for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland selling rural products, saw international sales grow in Europe and new markets. In its accounts, Harbro acknowledged challenging times in agriculture over the last 12-18 months and the uncertain impact of Brexit but expressed confidence in the industry's robustness and the group's positioning for future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, on Saturday afternoon, and another man in his 80s was taken to hospital; police are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, warning the public not to approach him as he is described as white, approximately 6ft tall with straight, greying, collar-length hair, of average build, and believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar; Detective Chief Inspector Martin Brunning stated the investigation is in its early stages and police urge anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers while conducting additional patrols for resident reassurance.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, outlined significant risks in a speech, stating the global economy shows a weakening baseline and is at a "delicate juncture," which follows China reporting weaker-than-expected trade figures with a 25% year-over-year plunge in exports; the IMF anticipates downgrading its current 3.4% global growth forecast in April, presenting ongoing ramifications for businesses relying on China's growth.

The council leader announced free Cowes ferry crossings until July 2nd to acknowledge problems and enable feedback, while an auditor review of the project was ordered, following a frustrating start since the ferry's late May 14th launch which included breakdowns, running aground, Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspension due to training issues, and vehicle damage during boarding; a local shopkeeper highlighted severe business losses from almost six months of lost trade and asked for compensation matching that for damaged cars, which the transport councillor confirmed was under discussion, adding that while it was a prototype with inevitable teething problems, electrical faults were fixed, ramp extensions authorized to resolve vehicle scraping, and grounding issues related to seamanship had been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene; a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for police investigation.

Matching Models, a London temp agency for "beautiful and talented people," advertised a personal assistant role specifying physical attributes like "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup," prompting condemnation from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and women's rights campaigners calling it "straight out of the 1970s." The EHRC demanded clarification of hiring practices, while the agency's founder Nathalie Jansen defended their approach, stating clients value looks and citing examples like a client hiring multiple blonde, blue-eyed Greek women for his plane and another requiring a specific cup size to fit a Dior outfit. Employment lawyers deemed the ads "clearly unlawful" under the 2010 Equality Act, noting they likely discriminate based on sex and age, with potential for unlimited compensation claims via tribunals. The agency, which serves clients including MTV and Louis Vuitton, claimed on its website that requesting attractive candidates is essential for first impressions, a stance Ms. Jansen reiterated.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, a school office assistant, allegedly fatally shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and severely injured another student, Sirisha, who is now out of danger; Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt on Wednesday and remanded until April 12, with the motive unclear, though gun crimes at Indian schools are rare despite the country's strict gun control laws and a history of feuds involving firearms, and a past incident in 2007 near Delhi saw a 14-year-old schoolboy shot dead by fellow students.

GLAAD's analysis of scripted TV series from June 2016 to May 2017 identified 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters rising from seven to sixteen; however, it noted over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD President Sarah Kate Ellis stated it was "heartening to see progress being made" but emphasized that numbers are "only part of the story."

Conservative MP David Mackintosh for Northampton South announced his resignation ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy faced expected opposition, following criticism over a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC while he was council leader that vanished and is now under police investigation for financial irregularities, leaving the stadium half-built; despite denying wrongdoing, a majority of his local party executive planned to deselect him, leading him to state it was time for constituents to have a new representative after previously intending to seek re-election.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; he was subsequently fired for policy violations and faces murder charges, which carry a potential sentence of 5 to 99 years, alongside four counts of aggravated assault for the other teenagers in the car. Police initially misrepresented the incident, claiming the car reversed aggressively, but body footage showed it was driving away; Oliver, currently free on bail, could be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. District Attorney Faith Johnson emphasized the thoroughness of the proceedings, while the Edwards family's lawyer, Lee Merritt, expressed caution given the rarity of police convictions in Texas, noting Jordan was highly praised by his coach.

Melania Trump plans to delay moving to the White House until her son Barron finishes school, a decision that sparked significant criticism on social media about tradition, though some supported her parenting priorities; historically, only two First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, while Frances Cleveland lived there only during social seasons, and experts note it's common for presidents' children to finish school before moving; Melania's focus aligns with past parents like Dolley Madison and reflects a potentially less active public role than predecessors, though she may support anti-cyberbullying, and speculation exists Ivanka Trump might assist, as Chelsea Clinton did; previous families like the Clintons and Obamas managed school transitions differently, moving early and maintaining normalcy, with First Ladies varying in public engagement, from active figures like Eleanor Roosevelt to more private ones like Nancy Reagan.

A 72-year-old man died at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October this year, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to his call; Police Scotland states it is fully cooperating with the scrutiny, and Pirc will report its findings to COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning was issued for gusts up to 75mph locally, particularly west of mountains, with the unusual easterly direction heightening impacts; disruption to road and sea travel was expected, affecting Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys, and a tree downed by overnight gusts in Menai Bridge closed Telford Road for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants scored first through player-coach Derrick Walser but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers; in the second period, Mike Forney's powerplay goal put the Panthers up 2-1, Andy Bohmback leveled the score, Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling reduced the deficit to 4-3. The teams will play again on Saturday night in their double-header, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, Sheffield Steelers on 27, and Belfast on 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix featured a chaotic first lap with multiple collisions, damaging Hamilton's front wing and causing an early safety car; Hamilton started from the back, incurred five pit stops, finished behind Raikkonen after Ferrari's advantageous tire strategy allowed him to pass, and faces a 36-point deficit to Rosberg, who won comfortably after Ricciardo's early puncture from a promising start. Vettel finished second despite contact with teammate Raikkonen, while Raikkonen recovered to fifth passing Hamilton later; V angrily confronted Kvyat over his aggressive move causing the initial pile-up. Hamilton's car sustained significant aerodynamic and suspension damage limiting his recovery from the rear.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality in a Die Zeit interview, stating he did so to address a topic "simply ignored" in German football and becoming the most prominent footballer to do so; his announcement garnered widespread praise and support from figures across football, including teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, administrators such as former DFB President Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga President Reinhard Rauball (who called it a "huge and courageous step"), international players like Gary Lineker and Joey Barton, his former club Bayern Munich, German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, and openly gay politician Volker Beck; this act is seen as a "watershed moment" in tackling the sport's homophobia, with Zwanziger noting football remains a "hard business" where sexual orientation discourse isn't normalized, highlighted by historical context including Philipp Lahm's 2011 discouragement of players coming out and Marcus Urban's 2007 revelation about closeted Bundesliga players;各方 expressed hope that Hitzlsperger's courage would break the taboo, encourage others, and lead to a future where sexual orientation isn't an issue in football.

Steve Sidwell, 34, made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping Brighton secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years; with his contract expiring, he hopes to sign a new deal, believing Brighton can stay in the top flight, a level he has previously played at with several clubs, while Brighton, confirmed as promoted after a win over Wigan, now leads Newcastle by four points and aims to wrap up the title in their final two matches, and Sidwell, who joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in 2016, feels he has performed better than expected and earned the opportunity for a new contract.

Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes from Nathan Delfouneso's assist, but Colchester United equalized via Kurtis Guthrie from a corner following a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made crucial saves to deny Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Colchester missed opportunities to take the lead, including Guthrie hitting the bar just before halftime and Tom Aldred heading wide late on for Blackpool. The match ended 1-1, with Colchester finishing with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues during their League One relegation last season and has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston; he could debut for the U's against Aston Villa in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie, following Colchester's season-opening 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside Parliament in March intensified calls for a permanent UK Police Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire, prompting the UK Police Memorial Trust to appeal for £1.5m towards its construction out of a total cost of £4m, with the government contributing £1m; the memorial, dedicated to over 1,400 officers and staff who died on duty over 250 years, will bear their names and feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts given to families, and is expected to be completed by 2019 as a lasting tribute to police courage and sacrifice.

Manchester United secured a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, extending their lead at the top of the table to 15 points with eight games remaining; manager Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing solely on upcoming matches, praising the players for creating a record of 25 wins in their first 30 matches and highlighting their 50-point haul from the last 18 Premier League games as they aim to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record, while also confirming injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea sustained during the match and indicating changes for the upcoming FA Cup replay at Chelsea, including potential availability of rested players Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez, and describing the second half as a difficult battle where United's determined defending secured the win.

Google Chairman Eric Schmidt stated the company paid what was "legally required," which amounted to £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, and argued it is the government's responsibility to change the tax system if it wants more revenue, emphasizing Google complies with the law as it exists. Schmidt pointed out Google routes most UK sales through Ireland to minimize tax, a practice widely criticised, and reiterated his belief that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs, not where products are consumed, calling for international tax reform. Concurrently, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Affairs Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements by hearing evidence in secret to bypass confidentiality rules, while EU leaders agreed to tackle avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt maintained politicians should set the rules and that companies abiding by the law deserve political defense, advocating for a clearer, simpler system.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the £3.6bn agency staff bill by £1bn this financial year through a 55% cap on shift rates introduced in October, which has saved £600m so far; while progress is deemed promising, trusts are still 10% behind target, and concerns remain over potential increases in other pay costs and excluded categories like NHS "bank" staff and overtime, leading to plans for publishing league tables and top earner data to address overcharging examples, such as surgeon rates quoted double the cap.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's Celtic Tiger era, now represents the economic crash, yet local traders report tentative recovery signs, with Matt O'Brien's clothing shop seeing increased business after diversifying into childrenswear and dress-hire despite laying off staff; politically, Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's €500m water meter spend versus broadband and alleges IDA neglect of Longford, while the government points to the planned €200m Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, expected to create 1,000 jobs by 2019 and boost tourism, though it requires planning permission and confidence from local TD James Bannon; however, traders like O'Brien believe more local support, such as free parking, is needed alongside these larger projects.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium with eight teams playing each other twice in a round-robin format, where the top four sides qualify for the play-offs consisting of Qualifier 1 (24 May), the Eliminator (25 May), Qualifier 2 (27 May), and the Final (29 May). Leading performers include Warner (top run-scorer with 294 runs and most sixes with 12), Kohli (second with 267 runs, 8 sixes), De Villiers (third with 249 runs, 12 sixes), De Kock (highest score of 108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*), and McClenaghan (most wickets with 9). Four England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). A complete fixtures and results schedule is provided, running from 25 April to 29 May, with most matches starting at 15:30 BST and some at 10:30 BST.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bag usage since 2013, as these mostly non-recyclable bags are often discarded after use, causing significant environmental problems by ending up in landfills and rivers. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge per plastic bag starting in October, aiming to encourage reuse; similar charges already implemented in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have successfully reduced bag consumption, and campaigners anticipate the English charge will also lessen bag disposal, thereby benefiting the environment.

Strong winds caused a school roof damage at Rhosgadfan and power cuts to hundreds of homes in Wales, leading to train delays, cancelled Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and speed restrictions on the A55 Britannia and M48 Severn bridges; the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to the wind, and although restrictions eased on Friday evening following the yellow warning, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to December 27th due to the blustery forecast.

Michael Jordan expressed excitement about joining Black Panther, hinting at an unspecified role but not elaborating, and reunites with Creed director Ryan Coogler; he anticipates working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, noting their past acclaimed roles including Nyong'o's Oscar win and Boseman's current Black Panther appearance, while also referencing Jordan's Human Torch in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o's Maz Kanata in Star Wars; the film is scheduled for February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875 and unused for decades but retaining original decor and stage machinery, will be restored for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music, alongside the repair and refurbishment of BBC studios at the eastern end, as part of a larger £26.6m east wing restoration project aiming to transform the Palace into a cultural destination, which includes converting the glazed east court into a public exhibition space; funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m) and Haringey Council (£6.8m), with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committed to raising the final £1m by summer 2017, the theatre is hoped to reopen in 2018 if funding is secured.

James Milner, aged 30 and a former Manchester City player, made his senior England debut in 2009, earning 61 caps and being a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016; he holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46 since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifiers, while stating his recent retirement decision was "about common sense" and wishing Sam Allardyce, players, staff, and supporters future success.

Marcy Smith was awakened by her son David to their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador engulfed in flames; the family escaped safely but the house was destroyed and their pets died. David, awake during a FaceTime call, spotted the fire, enabling their escape just before flames consumed the kitchen.
