Mrs. Smith attributed the fire to trash burned in their wood stove, a routine action, and noted the fire alarm failed. The family fled in pyjamas but received donations from the community. Mrs. Smith expressed immense pride in David, crediting him solely with saving her and her daughter, though he does not yet grasp the significance of his actions.

An energy drinks giant is reportedly considering a £200m offer for Premier League club West Ham United, whose majority owners Sullivan and Gold bought over 85% of the club in 2010 in a £105m deal; since moving to London Stadium in August, the club has been linked with takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups, though Sullivan stated last year that while a minority stake could be sold to clear debts, he and Gold intend ownership to pass to their children.

The awards ceremony, noted by Jillian Bell as different from the Oscars, featured fan-voted categories including Best Shirtless Performance won by Zac Efron and functioned as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking Best Movie, while its star Shailene Woodley won Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award, and Best Kiss (with Ansel Elgort), dedicating her speech to author John Green. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for Best Male Performance (American Sniper), Channing Tatum for Best Comedic Performance (22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep for Best Villain (Into the Woods), Kevin Hart for Comedic Genius, and Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award presented by his Avengers co-stars. The event also showcased trailers for upcoming films like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

Smith, 21, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has since scored five goals this season; having made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, he scored four goals in 89 appearances for them and is a Scotland Under-21 international. St Mirren boss Jack Ross described Smith's acquisition as "brilliant," stating he is a good, mature player who provides another attacking option, and the Championship bottom side will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has activated its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes due to sufficiently warm weather, aiming to fill 145 potholes each day over the next four months, while additional staff are repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

Last December, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during shutdown activities without proper personal protective equipment; rigging supervisor Steve Innes reported they learned of the contamination partway through, face cancer fears with ongoing tests, and claimed EnQuest failed its duty of care, while EnQuest confirmed the exposure was below the reportable threshold but notified the HSE and implemented additional precautions, Wood Group downmanned staff for assessments and reinforced safety commitments, Unite union criticized the workers' treatment, and the HSE stated it was aware but did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under current regulations and no staff contacted them separately.

The Asian Civilisation Museum purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007 for $650,000; later, the dealer's manager confessed during a 2012 court case that the company sold stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece suspected to be looted from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu; following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which made an official return request in May and could inspect other artworks bought from the dealer, the museum decided to return the sculpture, citing the confession as a factor despite no conclusive theft proof, and plans legal action for compensation.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck near Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km with its epicenter in Garfagnana at 15:48 local time; it was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, causing no immediate injuries or damage but disrupting phone lines and power in Garfagnana, prompting school evacuations for precaution, and followed by several aftershocks. Italy is prone to quakes, including a deadly 2009 L'Aquila event (nearly 300 deaths) and a fatal May quake (>20 dead, magnitude-6) in the same area, while six scientists were convicted of manslaughter in 2012 for providing falsely reassuring information before the L'Aquila quake, leading to many staying indoors and dying. INGV expert Alessandro Amato described the latest tremor as "medium-strong," "fairly shallow," and unexpected.

The fruit remains attached to the plant and unripe, despite Austin Grant from Sheffield finally achieving success after doubting South Yorkshire's climate suitability, leading the 62-year-old grandfather to express extreme joy.

Rockstar delayed Grand Theft Auto V's release from 27 January to 24 March, stating the game needed extra testing and polish for quality assurance, though online heists will launch on consoles before the PC version; the PC edition promises enhanced graphics including 1080p at 60fps, support for up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations, while minimum PC specifications have been published, and the game previously set the record as the fastest-selling entertainment product ever in 2013.

76-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting "Squint (19)", having been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three times previously; judge Ansel Krut described the difficult-to-look-at but "quite extraordinary" work, depicting a medieval "leper squint" allowing undesirables to view church services, as technically subtle and minimal, yet building a broad field of sympathy; Simpson, part of a series including larger works, chose the relatively small (7ft) painting due to familiarity and plans to spend the prize money on art materials like quality paints; the biennial John Moores Prize, established in 1957, is a prestigious British award with past winners like David Hockney.

Masked assailants simultaneously attacked the offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit in Istanbul early on Thursday, setting fire to the Yeni Safak building which was extinguished by firefighters, and shattering windows with gunfire at both locations where police found numerous spent bullet casings; no casualties were reported and no group claimed responsibility, while police cordoned off the areas and are hunting the attackers, with both papers supporting President Erdogan's AK Party and occurring 20km apart, marking a contrast to a prior September incident where pro-government protesters attacked the Hurriyet daily.

A 24-year-old player, contracted to the Stags, has agreed a free transfer to Marcus Bignot's side, the Mariners, effective 1 January, becoming Bignot's first signing; he spent the first half of this season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances and previously played for Burton.

Arsène Wenger, with his club contract expiring soon and linked to the England manager position, has stated he focuses solely on his current job. Gareth Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce, has overseen England's 2-0 win over Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia; Wenger praised Southgate's accumulated experiences and observation skills, noting the importance of competency over big names and that Southgate must prove his decisions correct. Southgate faces crucial upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to secure the permanent role. Wenger also confirmed defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, expressing surprise at transfer speculation linked to Barcelona and Manchester City, stating Bellerin's long-term future is at Arsenal. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury sustained against Liverpool in August.

Officers believe a local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday; Lincolnshire Police, in a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, stated the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement ending the dispute over low pay for seafarers on freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, where the RMT union claimed some workers earned below £4 an hour. Operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, who argued the national minimum wage didn't apply to non-UK resident crew, the service will return directly to Serco Northlink next month after Seatruck declined Serco's offer to bridge and backdate the pay gap. Subject to finalizing financial and regulatory details, the new charter will ensure all crew members receive at least the minimum wage, resolving the long-running issue for the government-subsidized Northern Isles ferry service operated under Serco's £243m contract awarded in 2012.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May following an incident six days earlier at Rockley Park in Poole; Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother Samantha Mitchell, 57, with whom Mr Dickie had a relationship. Mr Mitchell had accompanied his mother and Mr Dickie to the holiday park bar on 7 May, got heavily intoxicated, and later had a confrontation outside with Mr Dickie, broken up by bystanders. Both Mr Mitchell and his mother pleaded guilty to common assault (in relation to the fight for Jamie) and attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police that Mr Dickie pushed Mrs Mitchell who pushed back, before Mr Mitchell later stated his attempt to push the couple apart caused a "tragic accident"; they will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the songwriter known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, died in London aged 66 after a brief battle with cancer, as confirmed by Warner/Chappell's Jon Platt. Born in Cleethorpes, he traced his musical influence to his father and transitioned from working in a frozen food factory to joining the disco band Heatwave, writing hits like "Boogie Nights" in the 1970s. His talent led producer Quincy Jones to recruit him for Michael Jackson's breakthrough album Off The Wall, penning tracks including "Rock With You," and later for Thriller, contributing the title track, "Baby Be Mine," and "The Lady in My Life," helping make it the best-selling US album ever. Temperton also wrote for artists like Anita Baker and Aretha Franklin, won a Grammy in 1990 for Quincy Jones's "Birdland," received two Oscar nominations for The Color Purple soundtrack, and summed up his songwriting philosophy as writing something he loved first. Tributes poured in from figures like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and Gilles Peterson following his private funeral.

Researchers from Swansea University, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, alongside teams from Exeter, Reading, SÃ£o Paulo, and BelÃ©m, discovered over 450 large, ancient geometric geoglyphs, potentially 2,000 years old, hidden in Acre state, Brazil, by rainforest until deforestation revealed them. The function of these ditched enclosures remains little understood, as they lack defensive features or significant artifacts, suggesting they were possibly used sporadically as ritual gathering places, akin to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge, though Dr Loader's analysis of soil samples (phytoliths, charcoal, isotopes) indicates they were built within taller forest vegetation and not visible above the canopy. The research challenges the notion of a pristine pre-European Amazon, revealing evidence over 6,000 years of humans artificially concentrating economically valuable trees like palms, transforming the environment into a "prehistoric supermarket" rather than burning large forest tracts, with tantalizing evidence that some remaining forests retain a biodiversity legacy from these ancient agroforestry practices.

Australian Nick Kyrgios, aged 21 and ranked a career-high 12th, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the tournament in Shanghai, following his recent Japan Open win which has him close to the top 10; Kyrgios cited boredom, tiredness from his Japan success and travel, poor sleep, late arrival, and a difficult commute to the courts as reasons for his subdued performance after being fined last year at the Shanghai Masters for a foul-mouthed outburst describing the event as a "circus".

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination to boys to protect against increasing head and neck cancers, which HPV causes 5% of globally, alongside the existing programme for girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer; these cancers are rising in younger, mainly male non-smokers averaging age 55, and organisations including Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV team are delivering a letter calling for immediate action, though the Welsh government states it awaits recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes, having achieved an 85% vaccination rate among girls since 2008.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil diagnosed with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma in August, documented his fight and positive outlook on the "Jak's Journey" Facebook page, attracting over 28,000 Likes, which shared his love for Rangers FC, meetings with players, hospital stays in Edinburgh and Glasgow, and visits from sports teams and performers; he briefly attended a school prom held in his honour, greeted by Barry Ferguson, and received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy, but left feeling unwell after 10 minutes; on 23 January, Jak and his family learned his cancer had spread throughout his body and doctors ceased further treatment, after which they encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research and Jak shared personal moments until his death, announced by his mother Allison on Facebook.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a drab match with few chances on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, where Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said's winning goal in the 89th minute after Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had an earlier goal correctly disallowed for offside; Egypt struggled to overcome Uganda's resolute defense for long periods, with Uganda failing to register a shot on target, and the victory means Egypt advances to face Ghana for top spot in Group D while Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament since 1978.

Lancashire County Council has selected land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College (Westbank campus) for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, following a Network Rail comparative study, as the original station closed in 1956. Plans developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council include two direct hourly trains to Liverpool; the chosen site offers size for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity to the town. The council will now begin acquiring the land, aiming to serve Skelmersdale, one of the largest northwest English towns without a station since its designation as a new town in 1961.
Police found plants during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, describing the setup as an "elaborate grow house," and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found severely injured on a Hamelin pavement late Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old German ex-partner of Kurdish origin from Bad Muender subsequently turned himself in to police. The motive remains unclear, investigators have secured the scene, and they are appealing for witnesses.

Research by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzing 4,600 Australian workers, found women ask for pay rises as frequently as men but are 25% less likely to receive one when they ask, debunking theories that women avoid such requests due to reluctance, fear of upsetting bosses, or stereotyping; the study compared like-for-like full-time and part-time workers, controlling for employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications, using unique Australian data tracking requests, and while suggesting possible discrimination, it noted women under 40 now negotiate as successfully as men, indicating potential future progress.

Oxford City Council has spent money investigating potential burial sites but found none suitable within the city; Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. Council Member Linda Smith stated they have searched for years but, like housing sites, suitable land is exhausted, with council-owned sites being discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. After the current cemeteries fill, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible, and the last increase in burial space occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19-22 July) offers an augmented reality app allowing visitors to trigger online content like videos and band interviews from physical items like signs and posters; performers include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean; festival director Caroline Maclennan states the AR feature enhances the on-site experience and enables global interaction, with content updated before and during the event for instant access to information, interviews, tickets, and a taste of the festival atmosphere.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham, suffered a severe pulmonary haemorrhage confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA), which stated such incidents are rare even in horses without prior health issues and pledged efforts to understand and prevent them; despite having a history of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he showed no such symptoms before or during the race where he narrowly defeated Thistlecrack, and his trainer called him the "horse of a lifetime," though questions were raised about his past condition, the conclusion was that the haemorrhage was the cause with no significant underlying health issues linked.

Davina (formerly David Ayrton), now 34, was convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004; she denied the charge but will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody at a male prison in Winchester due to substantial grounds for believing she would be a risk to herself and risk failing to attend, noting the case was unusual and not easy. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer, and protocols exist for her detention. During the trial, she stated she had not made physical changes or taken medication regarding her sexuality and changed her name in 2012. The victim recalled being attacked despite shouting and swearing as her friends slept nearby, having consumed only "a can and a half of Foster's," and Ayrton confessed to the rape to a care home worker in 2014.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian partner lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in a Rio doubles match, a day after Djokovic was defeated in singles by Juan Martin del Potro; world number one Djokovic, 29, had previously suffered a surprise third-round Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey in July but then won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors will participate in Saturday's carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, with entrants from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Competitors must use only chainsaws to carve logs into shapes of animals and people, as other tools are banned. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is returning to defend his title and win the Claymore Trophy.

Webb suffered a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September and hasn't played since, but the 27-year-old is now close to return, currently progressing through a pre-season stage; he aims to be fit for February's Six Nations, successfully asking physios to reduce his return timeline from the target date, with Wales starting their campaign against Ireland on February 7; capped 16 times by Wales, Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys, where he debuted in 2007, and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay at his home region and position himself best for national selection.

Two men carrying backpacks containing 26kg of ecstasy were intercepted by US border agents near Sumas, Washington; one fled after firing at agents and was later arrested in Canada, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately detained. A forged California driver's licence linked Nathan Hall (the fugitive) to the name William Nickerson was found in the backpacks. Kali Henifin, accused of planning to pick the men up, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, allegedly hired to drive the drugs to San Francisco for $11,000, were also arrested after monitoring police radio and hearing about the shooting. Laviolette, Henifin, and Lambert face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges in US custody.

Childline counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12, with the true number likely higher; children as young as seven reported torment, abuse, and school avoidance due to online trolls causing misery and humiliation. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, called the figures a wake-up call, stating cyber-bullying relentlessly follows children home, becoming inescapable persecution that worsens without adult intervention from parents and teachers, emphasizing schools must take it seriously and children must seek help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, where the Anti-Bullying Alliance works with others to combat the issue, illustrated by a young person describing online harassment telling them to kill themselves, parental misunderstanding of the distress, and the difficulty of stopping the abuse

Israel postponed a vote on new settlement homes in Jerusalem at Prime Minister Netanyahu's request to avoid straining US relations before Secretary of State Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, following the US decision to abstain from vetoing a UN resolution declaring Israeli settlements illegal under international law, which Netanyahu's office accused the US of helping draft and push for – an accusation the State Department denied but expressed hope the resolution would serve as a "wake-up call"; over 500,000 Jews live in settlements considered illegal by most of the world though Israel disputes this, and the resolution stated settlements are a major obstacle to peace, leading Israel to summon ambassadors, recall diplomats, and cut aid, while Kerry plans to outline his peace vision and counter Israeli criticisms, and Palestinian leader Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for a French peace conference seeking an end to the occupation.

Prince William praised the Queen on her 90th birthday eve as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, highlighting her duty, service, tolerance, and commitment, while addressing personal criticisms about his work ethic by affirming his serious approach to duty and his gradual development into the role. Birthday events included the Queen visiting Windsor's Royal Mail office (marking its 500th anniversary), opening a new bandstand adorned by schoolchildren who sang to her, and the release of commemorative stamps featuring a four-generation royal portrait. Political figures like David Cameron paid tribute at Prime Minister's Questions. Her actual birthday plans involve a Windsor walk unveiling The Queen's Walkway plaque (honoring her record-breaking reign) and lighting beacons, followed by lunch with the Obamas the next day, though a republican group criticized the extensive coverage as disproportionate.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match, with Diafra Sakho scoring his first goal since November and Andre Ayew quickly adding a second goal into the same bottom corner after receiving passes from Sam Byram, giving the Premier League side control despite Cheltenham's bright start. Cheltenham, unchanged from a league defeat, had chances including a Harry Pell volley, a Jordon Forster header, and a low Pell cross that substitute Dan Holman narrowly failed to convert, while West Ham missed further opportunities and were denied by goalsaving clearances and saves from Kyle Storer and Jonathan Flatt. The victory ended League Two's representation in the competition and occurred four years after the clubs' only prior meeting, a narrow West Ham win.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to spot the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right, causing the crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, was fined £1,000, and received a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family saw no value in Werner being jailed, accepting it was a momentary lapse, and Werner expressed remorse, offering no explanation for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, London, is considered one of Britain's most dangerous returning jihadists and faces a possible life sentence after going to Syria under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani last January, where he joined the pro-Islamic State group Rayat al Tawheed, known for producing slick propaganda that glamorized jihad for young British Muslims while also posting gruesome content including an image of Khawaja holding a severed head; he faked his death online to return undetected via Bulgaria with his cousin Tahir Bhatti's help, but was arrested at Dover in June, admitted four terrorism offenses, and was held in a high-security unit at Belmarsh prison, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting him, and a serious charge of soliciting murder was dropped but remains on file.

Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth, has joined Barnsley as their third signing for next season ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday, with caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom stating Jackson has pace to burn, likes to attack defenders, and will fit Barnsley's style of play, after Jackson turned down a new contract offer from Wrexham.

Sealed bottles suspected to contain detergent have been washing up on Cornish beaches including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion since Sunday, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to risks to wildlife from potential leaks; while the Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' near Land's End in May, current evidence linking it to the bottles is circumstantial, prompting Cornwall Wildlife Trust's concern for sensitive marine life and Cornwall Council's warnings for the public to keep children and dogs away from any bottles and not attempt recovery, with ongoing monitoring by authorities.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people; the road was closed with diversions implemented via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions; he made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion, and manager Phil Parkinson noted he was "a bit of a forgotten man" but made an excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign, and Dervite has now signed a new contract following Bolton's promotion to the Championship, alongside teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan.

Liberal Democrat Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything", and Labour's Baroness Smith responded that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope", fracturing their previous cooperation that inflicted defeats on the government over EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval; Labour labelled Lib Dem insistence on these rejected amendments "grandstanding for campaign leaflets", while the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through" government plans for a "hard Brexit", though they have historically allied on other issues like education and housing; despite Lib Dem willingness to work together again, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" with interactions remaining "business-like".

In the current UK election, defense ranks low among voter priorities, with cuts having reduced military capabilities like the army to 82,000 personnel, the navy to 19 warships, and the RAF to seven front-line jet squadrons, creating gaps such as the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft; defense spending is projected to fall below NATO's 2% GDP target to 1.7% by decade's end, damaging UK credibility and likely forcing further cuts despite global instability, while renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent lacks consensus and new aircraft carriers face manning and equipment shortages, risking a "hollow force" unable to match political rhetoric.

Barcelona denies committing any tax-related offense regarding Neymar's transfer but made a supplementary tax payment of €13.55 million to cover potential interpretations, stating it believes the original payment was correct, while Neymar's total cost to the club including fees, wages, and agents is £106.8m; former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation, which he denies, and a Spanish judge recently ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating the deal, though Barcelona maintains its innocence and the case's status after the payment remains unclear.

Michael Luciw, 27, a father and delivery driver from Nottingham, died in a crash on the M1 motorway near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October when the van he was a passenger in, driven by Andy Harrington, was hit head-on by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died; Luciw's family, describing him as generous and kind-hearted, called for retired people to undergo regular driving tests, arguing age slows reactions, while Harrington, seriously injured, advocated for medical examinations for older drivers; Age UK countered that it's vital older people can drive safely for independence and the DVLA stated there are no plans for age-based restrictions, as evidence doesn't show older drivers cause more serious accidents, with over-70s currently self-assessing every three years without tests.

The passage details controversy over transvaginal mesh implants in Scotland, where many women suffered debilitating side effects after incontinence treatment, leading patient representatives Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes to quit an independent review group in protest over a "watered-down" report; independent expert Alison Britton will now examine the review's process and lessons learned, while the report itself recommended against routine procedures, stressed informed patient choices with alternative treatments, and mandated adverse event reporting; Health Secretary Shona Robison confirmed implementing these recommendations despite campaigner demands for a ban, noting UK regulators held banning authority, while review chairperson Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to achieve consensus and faced public outcry from affected women during her testimony; over 20,000 Scottish women received mesh implants in 20 years, with over 400 pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m record by 14 seconds in Glasgow with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan initially raised concerns about the ratification, questioning if the mixed 3K race (where only Muir completed the 5K) met UK Athletics criteria like being a "genuine race" and if drug testing was in place. However, British Athletics confirmed ratification was expected, noting rules do not require doping control at the event for record ratification. McColgan expressed excitement her record was broken by Muir, praised her performance and potential ("world class"), predicted she could run as fast as 14:30 to compete globally, and noted the similarity to her own record run where she lapped other runners. She also mentioned Muir's recent British 1500m record and Olympic final appearance.

Jung won gold aboard Sam, a late replacement for the infected Fischertakinou, while France's Astier Nicolas took silver and America's Phillip Dutton secured bronze; GB's William Fox-Pitt, competing 10 months after an induced coma from a fall, finished 12th despite a faultless show-jumping round, as his medal hopes were dashed by time penalties in the cross-country phase having led after dressage, and Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth.

Andy Murray defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes at Wimbledon, saving five set points in the tense fourth set before winning five consecutive games to reach the last 16 for the 11th time, where he will play Benoit Paire; the match featured fading light, Fognini's double faults and temper leading to a point penalty for obscenity, Murray's complaints about slow play, and Fognini's ankle issue, with Murray expressing relief about finishing before conditions changed and noting he needs to improve his movement before Monday's match.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014; police arriving later found people still present and till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST, leading the judge to order the bar closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours; the defense admitted licensing laws were not followed and the bar was improperly run. The judge criticized Ms O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed inability to impose a custodial sentence, stating it was "as bad a case as I have come across." Ms O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist Party manifesto "Real Partnership," advocating partnership over domination and calling the election a referendum on the mishandling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, focusing on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. Despite controversy over his comments suggesting voters transfer support to the SDLP after unionist candidates, and colleague Danny Kennedy distancing himself, Nesbitt stood firm, denying regrets and emphasizing post-election governance. He expressed confidence in his position and differing candidate views on vote transfers, criticizing the DUP-Sinn Féin leadership as unchangeable while outlining manifesto priorities including tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, supporting infrastructure projects and LGBT rights, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly to pardon gay and bisexual men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, bringing the region in line with England and Wales’ 'Turing's Law'; this motion, which has secured executive agreement, is expected to contain provisions for both posthumous pardons and allowing living men to apply for a pardon, aiming to ensure equal treatment and right past wrongs more rapidly than through an assembly bill.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in four minutes, 19.12 seconds behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and moving second on the British all-time list; Muir expressed pleasure at setting the Scottish record, which she now holds alongside the Scottish mile and 1500m records, and noted it was her first season race at that distance while hoping to secure an Olympic place at the British trials in June; she recently won an 800m race in France and next competes in a 1500m in Stockholm, balancing training with her fourth year of veterinary studies.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive for the murder, but argued the Russian state was likely the sponsor, citing "reasons aplenty" and that the use of polonium-210 indicated state involvement; UK officials believe the suspects poisoned Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006 using radioactive tea, leading to his death nearly three weeks later, though the suspects deny wrongdoing. Horwell suggested Litvinenko's defection to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of corruption and murder, plus his criticisms of President Putin, could be seen as treachery and provided motives, while stressing this did not prove Putin's personal involvement. He noted Litvinenko was poisoned twice, the attacks caused great suffering, the suspects left a polonium trail with no credible explanation, and the long-term public health risk remains unknown; attempts to extradite the suspects have failed, making trial unlikely, and the inquiry was adjourned.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia's Test captain on an ongoing basis following Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat; Smith, who already leads the ODI and T20 teams and previously captained three Tests against India, has played 32 Tests scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, with selectors Rod Marsh stating he is highly regarded and the right man to succeed Clarke. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain despite a history of disciplinary issues; Marsh praised Warner's maturity and development into a senior figure, believing he will respond well to the added responsibility. Smith and Warner will now lead Australia in the limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, stating instead that "we are all sinners," but affirmed he was "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and that defending and extending equal marriage rights, including removing the spousal veto for transgender people, would be "at the top of my agenda." He explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill by stating it followed the defeat of a Liberal Democrat amendment focused on the "protection of individual liberties," while maintaining he "absolutely support[s] equality" and "equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality."

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, eliminating 450 jobs; Accord Healthcare is now set to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi staff, with Accord's spokesman predicting an "extremely positive" impact and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes hailing it as "fantastic news" that boosts the local economy and strengthens the region's science and healthcare sector, noting Accord's role as a global pharmaceutical firm developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 products to around 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis is leaving the council on Friday after his contract ends, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme; Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services; SNP group leader Stephen Flynn stated these exits indicate the council's failure to retain senior staff and predicted further departures in the coming months, and council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants detonated explosives at the gate of Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul, entered with guns and grenades, and opened fire on staff and patients; commandos landed on the roof and killed all four attackers after several hours, with the Islamic State claiming responsibility while the Taliban denied involvement, resulting in over 50 wounded. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack, which began at 09:00 local time, as trampling human values since hospitals are immune sites, and eyewitnesses described attackers including one wearing a white coat firing indiscriminately. This attack marked a change in IS tactics, being their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital using a method more associated with the Taliban, suggesting increased resources and training, though their expansion efforts beyond eastern Afghanistan have been limited so far, despite previous major attacks like the July 2016 rally bombing killing about 80 people and the Supreme Court attack last month killing 22. The government claims to have rooted out IS from some eastern bases but not mountainous areas they control, and the Taliban continues its own attacks, having killed 16 people in Kabul a week prior.

Martin crashed at this year's TT and his Honda Fireblade suffered mechanical problems; he initially stated he was quitting road racing but clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing, just has no plans to race Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix as he informed the team the bike wasn't competitive, leading to his withdrawal without notification. Martin found the TT a "bloody disaster" aside from racing the Mugen, feeling like a test rider, and now wants to race classics and oddball bikes with no unfinished business.

The APC won 19 of 28 governorship posts, handing the PDP its biggest defeat since 1999, following its prior presidential loss; the PDP lost key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa to the APC but retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the southeast, while Taraba's result was outstanding and Imo's inconclusive. The APC, gaining historic ground and relegating the PDP to a regional party concentrated in the southeast and Niger Delta, won most northern states and Lagos, but failed to capture any oil-producing states, posing challenges for President-elect Buhari regarding oil revenue and militancy. Despite violence, including 66 incidents particularly in southern Rivers, and ethnic rivalries, the elections were more peaceful than previous years. The PDP's decline stemmed from corruption allegations, failure to tackle the Boko Haram insurgency, voter fatigue after 16 years, and pre-election defections, necessitating introspection and rebuilding. Governors wield significant power, with some controlling budgets larger than neighboring countries, and APC's Lagos win marks the first time the ruling party controls the commercial hub since 1999.

Mighty, a US environmental lobby group, accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder Temasek of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil sourcing practices that contribute to regional haze, including creating a "secretive market" for products from unknown sources; Olam rejects the allegations, stating a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and confirming it buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties while accounting for less than 1% of the global market, and Temasek dismissed the claims, emphasizing support for no-burn policies and non-interference in portfolio operations. The report also accused Olam of bulldozing rainforests in Gabon, which the company defended as responsible and transparent partnerships aligned with Gabon's sovereign rights.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors, with a clip showing this dog's dinner arrangement.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt with a knee injury after only being a substitute in recent games, Derby County striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury after missing the last match, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall following his late equalizer scored after coming off the bench.

Pakistan lifted its three-year ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, allowing the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request blocking of locally deemed "offending material" directly through an online process which YouTube will review before restricting access within the country. While YouTube clarified that government removal requests are not automatic and violations of its own guidelines are the primary reason for content removal, with all government requests recorded in its Transparency Report, many young Pakistanis welcomed the ban's lifting, although some activists demanded greater transparency about the terms of the government's agreement with Google. The original 2012 Supreme Court ban stemmed from protests over the "Innocence of Muslims" film, which mocked the Prophet Muhammad and resulted in over a dozen deaths in Pakistan, where blasphemy is a criminal offense punishable by death.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and Swiss-Italian like candidate Gianni Infantino, faces demands from Liberia FA boss Musa Bility to withdraw by Thursday due to shared nationality, citing Article 7.4 of FIFA's Electoral Regulations on conflict of interest; Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, arguing consistency is needed after Scala and Claudio Sulser voluntarily stepped down for the 2015 election involving Swiss incumbent Sepp Blatter, while Scala's spokesman contends no conflict exists in this election with five candidates and no incumbent, as relevant regulations do not mandate withdrawal solely for shared nationality, leaving Bility's threatened legal action pending ahead of the February 26th vote to replace Blatter by FIFA's 209 members, with candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali (endorsed by Bility), Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed on Monday shortly after 09:00 BST while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, a company that makes digger buckets. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, and a forensic search has been conducted. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham stated significant progress has been made, with evidence suggesting a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source created a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive, involving inspectors and electrical safety experts, is gathering evidence.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to Caf for complaints lodged after a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament, where they disputed a late penalty but denied accusing Caf or the referee of corruption. Morocco, banned from the 2017 qualifiers for refusing to host the 2015 edition over Ebola fears and subsequently fined, successfully appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which overturned their ban and significantly reduced the fine, enabling their entry. Both nations, led by FA officials Maher Snoussi and Fouzi Lekjaa respectively, reported resolving differences with Caf and expressed optimism for the future and minimal impact from the disputes. They are set to participate in the 2017 tournament in Gabon, with Tunisia drawn in Group A against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome; Tunisia aims to secure a record thirteenth consecutive finals appearance.

During a mass fracas in the 95th minute of Chelsea's 3-1 win at Manchester City's Etihad Stadium, City forward Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for a second violent conduct dismissal this season (a late challenge on David Luiz), and City midfielder Fernandinho received a three-match ban for clashing with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas during the subsequent scuffle; Fabregas faces no further action, City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's involvement, and both clubs must respond to the related FA charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, prompting pilot diagnostic clinics in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focused on patients lacking clear symptoms but suspected by their GPs of having cancer, following Welsh doctors' study of Denmark's improved diagnostic systems. The current problem involves significant diagnostic delays for non-acute patients who don't fit specific pathways, leading to multiple GP referrals and lengthy testing, often resulting in treatment starting too late. The Cwm Cynon pilot allows 40 GPs to refer such patients directly to a diagnostic center at Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days, aiming for same-day tests and an estimated six patients weekly, with hopes of improving early diagnosis rates (currently only 35% in Cwm Taf for concerning symptoms). A similar clinic is planned for Singleton Hospital. These trials, developed over 12 months since Danish visits, aim to reassure patients and accelerate diagnosis, with doctors anticipating a major impact on outcomes. If the six-month Cwm Cynon trial succeeds, the service will expand area-wide.

England secured a dominant victory at Old Trafford, leveling the series, by setting a massive target and winning with a day to spare, marking their second-biggest win over Pakistan by runs; Joe Root was named man of the match for his exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, alongside taking catches and claiming a wicket, with praise coming from captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss for his responsibility and control; Pakistan's batting collapsed, scoring only 198 and 234 over few overs due to poor shot selection, leaving captain Misbah-ul-Haq disappointed though hopeful their strong characters will recover, while former players Geoffrey Boycott and Michael Vaughan lauded England's all-round dominance and predicted further success, with the series poised to remain tight before the third Test.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as an interim coach, while Wales forwards coach McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for their summer tour, his third time leading the team overseas, stating it is an honour and an exciting opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is finalizing assistant coaches for McBryde, with CEO Martyn Phillips noting they are in advanced discussions and aim to confirm the full management team soon. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour benefits Welsh rugby, calling 2017 a summer of opportunity for coaching development that will stimulate and inspire individuals, building on past positive experiences.

Southampton led through Charlie Austin's early penalty, but Hull City lost starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries before substitute Robert Snodgrass sparked a turnaround in the 61st minute with a goal from Sam Clucas' cross, followed moments later by a Snodgrass free-kick assist for Michael Dawson's header; Southampton pushed for an equaliser, with Virgil van Dijk hitting the bar and David Marshall making several saves before Snodgrass, Clucas, and Dawson combined for crucial defensive blocks, including Clucas' remarkable goal-line clearance in added time, securing Hull's first league win since August 20th and ending a six-game losing streak, though they remain in the bottom three.

A crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, resulting in the death of a local motorcyclist whose details police have not released; the tractor driver involved was uninjured, and Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses while closing the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings to "put an end to the agony" ahead of June elections, citing a need to "defend national interests" by cutting the "knot" of turmoil that began with the 2015 recordings; his move was condemned by opposition leader Zaev as illegal, prompting protests, and by EU Commissioner Hahn as contrary to the rule of law, risking Macedonia's EU ambitions, while the crisis stems from Zaev's release of thousands of leaked recordings since 2015 that he claims expose high-level corruption, vote-rigging, cover-ups, and illegal wiretapping—accusations the government denies while countering that Zaev aims to destabilize the nation.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking, with the club aiming to quickly appoint Paul Clement as the new manager due to serious relegation concerns. Curtis warns that relegation would make a swift return difficult given the Championship's strength and Swansea's likely inability to retain key players, unlike bigger clubs like Newcastle. He feels Swansea has lost its distinctive identity and "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, contrasting it with successful eras under Martinez, Rodgers, and Laudrup, while questioning player replacements. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to avoid relegation, educating new signings, particularly foreign players, about the club's remarkable rise from near-bankruptcy and the brink of leaving the Football League in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, often using the "Jack to a King" documentary to emphasize the critical importance of staying up for both the club and the local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge, needing victory to avoid relegation, lost 3-2 to Leyton Orient despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona after Orient led 2-0 via Jay Simpson; Armand Gnanduillet's winner relegated Dagenham to the National League, while Orient stayed in the play-off hunt under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler following Kevin Nolan's sacking. Dagenham, managed by John Still who previously led them from the Conference to League One and returned in December, had the worst goal difference in League Two, conceded significantly more goals than last season, and struggled in attack with Cureton scoring only nine compared to 20 previously. Still expressed commitment to achieving promotion next season, while Hessenthaler emphasized the need for professionalism to win games for the play-offs, and both managers commented on their teams' lack of discipline and organizational issues contributing to Dagenham's inevitable defeat.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to the club as a youth coach in February in his first job since retiring as a player; manager Jürgen Klopp endorsed the appointment after discussing Gerrard's future ambition to become a manager, which Klopp stated is a role that requires learning and combining with his playing experience for a bright future. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998, left for LA Galaxy in 2015 after winning the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup (twice), and League Cup (three times), and retired in November following a 19-year career; he turned down the MK Dons manager job as too soon and is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence required for Premier League management.

McManus scored first for Morton after 15 minutes, quickly followed by a deflected goal from Ross Forbes to double their lead. Alloa's Kyle McAusland pulled a goal back before halftime, but McManus netted again and Denny Johnstone added a late strike, securing a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted found evidence of children taught in squalid conditions at three now-closed illegal schools in Birmingham, leading to owner investigations and potential jail sentences up to 51 weeks; inspectors visited 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim Midlands communities, with Sir Michael Wilshaw expressing shock and concern about abuse/radicalization risks, calling it the "tip of the iceberg"; while places teaching over 20 hours weekly must register legally, some "part-time centres" exploit home education rights illegally; Wilshaw criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice; a new six-inspector team will investigate illegal schools across all religious groups; the Education Secretary intends to prosecute unregistered schools with her consent, and a government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin operates from the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, emerging as proposals advance for the region's first whisky distillery since 1837, with lead distiller Kate Macinnes expressing excitement about establishing a "region of distilling excellence." The gin is produced on a small scale within a cowshed using one of the UK's smallest production stills, focusing on capturing the local flavour palette of the Teviot valley and Borders "terroir" through abundant local wild botanicals. John Henderson of Born in the Borders views the gin distillery as a natural companion to their on-site brewery and commends its commitment to local sourcing, aligning with their ethos. Named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine who fought at the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor near the distillery, the name was chosen to reflect both the landscape and the strong female production team.

Gary Green, aged 51, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in Rothwell near Leeds in August 2013, causing Harry's death; Green was found to be more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer beforehand. Leeds Crown Court jailed Green for 16 months and two weeks after he admitted failing to ensure the safety of others, prosecuted under health and safety legislation as the incident occurred on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, stated their close-knit family was "changed forever," emphasized that driving drunk is unacceptable anywhere, and expressed hope Harry would be remembered beyond the accident day. A Health and Safety Executive investigation revealed Harry was walking towards a worker in a closed-off area when Green backed into him at 09:15 on 9 August, with an inspector calling it "an extremely tragic case" and Green's behavior "reckless."

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) partially upheld FIFA's ban on Luis Suarez for biting Giorgio Chiellini, confirming his nine-match ban in competitive games but overturning the suspension on all football-related activities; consequently, Suarez can now train with Barcelona, play in friendly matches, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities, with his public presentation set for Monday, though he remains banned for the remaining eight competitive international matches and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely in October against Real Madrid, while Cas deemed FIFA's complete activity ban excessive and FIFApro expressed disappointment the sanctions weren't more strongly reduced, with reactions noting the importance of proportionality for repeat offenders like Suarez, who has history of similar incidents.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race on 18 March 2014, defeating Vytautas Kirkliauskas carrying his wife Neringa; Rich attributed their success to a week of training on a nearby athletics track. Competitors tackled a 380-metre course featuring hurdles over haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols; participation was not restricted to married couples, with various combinations including men carrying men and a woman carrying a woman. As winners, Rich and Anna qualified for the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond informed Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that job roles at the DVLA would change with the scrapping of paper tax discs in October 2014, following Chancellor George Osborne's announcement of an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments; concerns over job losses among the 5,000 DVLA workers arose, but Hammond clarified in his response that reductions in staff roles would be managed through redeployment to other business areas, not redundancies, providing comfort to employees despite a likely decrease in job opportunities, which Hedges acknowledged while noting the advantages of the new system.

Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto stated Hungary will not backtrack on laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which the EU objects to over potential EU law incompatibility, the forced asylum container housing, and the threat to Central European University's closure, declaring these domestic issues where the EU should not interfere and securing Poland's pledge to veto any EU sanctions attempting to strip Hungary of its voting rights, while European institutions, including Commission official Frans Timmermans, warn of imminent action unless withdrawn amid public protests against the right-wing government's measures.

Emma Watson stars as Belle in the live-action Beauty and the Beast, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Kevin Kline as her father Maurice, and Luke Evans as the villain Gaston; additional cast includes Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou and an unnamed star as Mrs. Potts, the teapot character voiced by Angela Lansbury in the original. Directed by Bill Condon, the film begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for US cinema release on March 17, 2017.

Columnist Adrian Gill, diagnosed with "the full English" of cancers months earlier, died suddenly, prompting tributes from colleagues like Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens, who called him "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper since 1993; Gill, known for his witty, fearless writing and dictating copy due to dyslexia, faced controversy for articles including shooting a baboon, offensive remarks about the Welsh, Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and Clare Balding, yet was widely praised for his brilliance and unique style by figures including Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, and Piers Morgan, while his personal life included marriages to Cressida Connolly and Amber Rudd, children from both relationships, and a fiancée, Nicola Formby, before his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator while performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia predating Nazi Germany; Russian reports stated he was hit with a bottle and kicked, but the Russian embassy called the reports "distorted" and is investigating, while his father confirmed he suffered serious head injuries including 10 days in a coma. The Russian embassy disputed the reported date, number of participants, and circumstances, and the suspect is an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer not arrested because police deemed the injury "not serious," not due to diplomatic immunity, though the victim's lawyer insists he must be investigated under Mongolian law. The musician, his father, and lawyer denied reports he shouted "Heil Hitler," emphasizing the swastika's traditional Mongolian roots, and the case remains under police investigation.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested Monday at 03:30 BST on Heathrow's northern runway against expansion plans, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area; they will appear in court on 19 August, and police announced a review of airport security.

Nick Selman's mature 101, his second first-class century after a string of low scores and being dropped early, dominated Glamorgan's total as seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, leaving Gloucestershire struggling; Aneurin Donald's quick 36 was the next best score, and Glamorgan scrambled a consolation bonus point, while Gloucestershire struggled to survive in the evening gloom with the day ending evenly balanced under stand-in captain Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee raised fears over a planned murder bid involving police being ambushed following a false report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he intended to shoot them; he admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week, with the court hearing the threats were made late at night while drunk and that he had a previous 2009 firearm conviction, while his legal team asserted he lacked intent to carry out any threat, and North Wales Police had been particularly concerned as he was on bail (later cleared) for firearms offences at the time.

After collapsing to 8-2, Surrey recovered to 255-7 thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase started poorly and faltered after Stuart Meaker (3-61) took three wickets in nine balls, including key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68 and Matthew Waite's 38, Yorkshire fell short, all out for 236 while needing 27 off the final three overs. Surrey captain Gareth Batty highlighted the crucial partnership and timely wickets, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment at the top order's failure despite the target being reachable.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST because its pump could not handle incoming water; the RNLI lifeboat crew then placed a pump on board and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, as her exams in May conflict with the April event; she finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 seconds in the latter, and expressed disappointment but prioritized completing her degree, while identifying the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and believing she has at least two or three more Olympics in her.

Robbie Savage argues Liverpool are far from repeating last season's title challenge due to unrealistic expectations raised by overachievement, significant struggles in attack following the sale of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, with new strikers Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini lacking quality and work-rate, leading to decreased intensity, pressing, and first-half goals compared to last season; defensively, despite heavy spending like £20m on Dejan Lovren, they remain disorganised and lack a leader, with goalkeeper Simon Mignolet not commanding his area adequately; Savage predicts Chelsea will win at Anfield, sees Steven Gerrard's physical and mental battle to extend his career, especially after his slip against them last season, as crucial but believes the 34-year-old remains a key player for Liverpool's future; he suggests securing Champions League qualification should be considered success this season and proposes a lineup against Chelsea featuring Fabio Borini up front and dropping Lovren for Kolo Toure.

The £45m facility at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, which East Ayrshire Council plans to name after renowned writer William McIlvanney, born and educated in the town, with council leader Douglas Reid highlighting McIlvanney's passion for education as the reason; McIlvanney, who died on 5 December at his Glasgow home, was an English teacher turned full-time writer from 1975, gaining immediate fame with his first novel "Remedy Is None" and becoming known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works like the Laidlaw trilogy, "Docherty," and "The Big Man," while also being an influential poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scottish political and sporting life.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s, found near Gourock's swimming pool on Monday, led to the evacuation of three streets for most of the morning and early afternoon, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m to stay indoors; an exclusion zone on the river and a half-mile zone at sea remains while experts make it safe, causing ferry disruptions and advising small boats not to sail; officials stated the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger, but the mine's deterioration prevented assessing its explosive content, necessitating its move before disposal.

UK Sport allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than Rio, setting medal targets of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and notably badminton—which won a bronze medal in Rio—lost all funding, with badminton officials criticizing the "incomprehensible" decision as "catastrophic" despite meeting its Rio target. Cycling itself received a £4m cut despite 12 Rio medals, while judo, which also won one bronze, saw a slight funding increase. UK Sport justified the cuts as necessary to prioritize medal potential, stating under-investment across the board risks success, and noted £9m remains unallocated with funding for new Olympic sports like baseball/softball and new Paralympic sports still pending based on medal potential exploration. Previously defunded team sports (basketball, volleyball, handball) accused UK Sport of having "no interest in team sports" and passing responsibility for their development.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks, one nine-storey and one seven-storey, containing 122 apartments; despite strong objections from English Heritage and others citing "severe harm" to the conservation area's historic character, councillors voted seven to three in favour of the development, arguing the existing buildings were no longer functional and the project would boost tourism and improve living for older people, though acknowledging the regrettable loss of buildings and trees.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was off-duty in Brecon for training when Jake Vallely punched and beat him unconscious outside a bar called The Cellar on the night of 8 May, with CCTV showing the attack; Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon," then dragged Boyd's body away and fled, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he left the scene before the violence began. Vallely, convicted of the murder which shocked the Brecon community, will be sentenced on 8 December. Boyd's family, describing him as a loving, caring "all-rounder" whose promising career was cut short, stated Vallely created "a void in our family that will never be filled" and countered his claim by highlighting the community's outpouring of love as demonstrating true strength. Senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney condemned the attack as a "despicable act" and urged people to walk away from conflict during nights out.

Andrew Travers departed Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an electoral error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names from poll lists, leading to an independent investigation; Travers stated he enjoyed his time and believed in the borough's future, while the council acknowledged his valuable contribution, naming John Hooton as temporary chief executive; on election day, only 3 of the first 30 voters at one station were registered, prompting council apologies and emergency proxy votes, though residents questioned the result's fairness; Travers blamed registration lists, and the council's review, concluding by late May with public findings, will examine arrangements for the EU Referendum while discussions continue on leading the investigation.

Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a fine free-kick, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before half-time with an equally fine set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead in the second half, heading Craig Baxter's cross into the net. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised the second-half performance and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half display and their failure to convert chances. The match ended with Gateshead defeating Wrexham 2-1.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measured the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, with Mozambique following Afghanistan.

OneWeb aims to deploy over 2,000 satellites, starting with 600, to provide global broadband coverage, particularly targeting schools, requiring Airbus to revolutionize satellite manufacturing with high-volume, low-cost assembly lines producing units for under $1 million each using car-like automation, with initial lines in Toulouse and Florida; the first satellites launch in April next year, followed by rapid deployment using over 20 Soyuz rockets, aiming for 300 satellites by early 2021 and over 600 a year later, competing with other mega-constellation projects like SpaceX while leveraging $1.7bn in equity financing and UK regulatory ties, and committing to strict debris mitigation by de-orbiting satellites within two years using enhanced hardware and adapter devices for potential removal.

Scottish Finance Minister John Swinney claims the UK government's spending review imposes "unprecedented pressure" due to ongoing austerity, reducing Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20, with £1bn in cuts still to come by the decade's end, yet he vows to protect schools, hospitals, and police services without sacrificing them to "austerity obsession," citing past achievements; the UK government rebuts that Scotland will have £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m with underspend, stating the deal is better than the alternative due to oil prices and urging focus on new powers; meanwhile, Labour criticizes Swinney for "anti-austerity posturing" lacking substance and demands a long-term budget offering a real alternative through different tax decisions.

People with severe disabilities and their carers face isolation and stress from inadequate standard accessible toilets, which lack space, hoists, and changing benches needed by those requiring two carers or transfer assistance; Changing Places toilets address this with enhanced facilities, but only 893 exist in the UK for an estimated 250,000+ people who need them, leading campaigners like Lorna Fillingham to push for making their installation compulsory in new large buildings rather than just recommended, as current guidelines allow designers to prioritize only mandatory regulations, while businesses cite logistical and cost barriers due to the larger 12m² size required, yet installations like at Arsenal FC show positive public reception and highlight the importance of accessibility.

Italian consumer organizations filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees and sign longer-than-average contracts, preventing them from switching competitors and allegedly leading to higher prices and poorer consumer choice in franchise stores compared to company-owned ones; McDonald's defended its model as sharing risks and rewards successfully with franchisees, while unions including the SEIU and the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union supported the complaint, urging the Commission to investigate McDonald's' alleged abuse of its dominant market position; the European Commission stated it will study the submission and can launch an investigation if it finds the allegations founded, noting franchisees own 73% of McDonald's European restaurants and the company generated $9.27bn from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign #prayforjosh, started by Bangor Elim Church for 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, went viral after an update was seen by over 79,000 people; a mystery donor subsequently funded a billboard displaying the hashtag in Holywood, leading to global support for the Bangor Grammar pupil and his family, initiated locally to seek prayers but spreading far beyond expectations.

UK military restructuring includes closing Brecon Barracks, a historic site since 1805 and home to troops at Rorke's Drift, prompting strong condemnation from local MP Chris Davies who views it as disrespectful to history and harmful to an area with high unemployment; despite the closure, jobs for its 85 civilian and 90 military staff are reportedly not at risk, and nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school will remain unaffected, while Defence Secretary Michael Fallon announced plans for a new specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, confirmed the 2024 closure of previously-announced Cawdor Barracks, and a 2025 storage depot shutdown at Sennybridge, with Labour Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supporting the restructuring but warning of uncertainty affecting livelihoods from base closures.

The passage details potential trade-offs in Brexit negotiations regarding fishing, warning the UK may need to allow EU boats access to its waters in exchange for tariff-free fish exports to the EU, despite fishing communities strongly backing Leave to escape the disliked Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain control. The House of Lords report highlights the industry's small economic size (0.5% GDP, 12,000 jobs) but warns it "must not be marginalised," noting complexities including shared fish stocks, reliance on EU exports, imports for UK consumption, international obligations, and the risk of fragmented management across UK regions if the CFP framework ends. While recommending scientific quotas be retained, the report also acknowledges industry optimism that Brexit offers opportunities for control, fairer shares, and sustainable management, exemplified by positive responses to recent CFP quota increases and statements anticipating a new era as an independent coastal state. The government affirms seeking maximum single market access while using Brexit to review fisheries for fairer quotas and sustainability.
