The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 on Southampton Water, operated for over 40 years, closing in 2013, and was capable of powering one million homes using fuel from the nearby Esso refinery via 1,100 miles of internal cable. The 300-acre site, dominated by the 198-metre-high chimney, was sold to the developers in 2016, who intend to keep the chimney as their signature piece, with outline planning permission due later this year and building potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong cycling championships, GB's Ollie Latham secured bronze in the men's scratch race behind Poland's Adrian Teklinski and Germany's Lucass Liss, marking GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver. GB's men's team pursuit lost the bronze medal race to Italy, while the women's team pursuit, featuring Barker and young riders Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, finished fifth in the heats and missed the bronze ride. GB rider Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint by China's Lin Junhong. Latham expressed happiness with his medal, while Marchant voiced disappointment, citing a lack of "zing" and focusing preparation towards Tokyo. Experts like Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's tactical sprint and positioning, and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted the youth and future potential of GB's women's pursuit squad.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell specifically for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character Peggy Mitchell, who has returned to reveal her cancer is back and will be killed off in emotional spring scenes; Kemp agreed to return because Barbara Windsor is a close friend and he felt it right for the Mitchell brothers to reunite with their mother one last time, with the show's producer highlighting the opportunity to showcase the iconic actors together as the legendary Grant, known for family dramas since arriving in 1990, comes home to say goodbye to Peggy and reunite with brother Phil amid this storyline.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds for Liverpool against second-placed Tottenham at Anfield, where manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and stated they are not ready to fight for the Premier League, warning that a Chelsea win would leave them 12 points clear, highlighting Spurs' poor away record with only two wins since September and just one victory in 17 away games against top-six rivals, while former midfielder Danny Murphy noted their defensive frailties and lack of pace away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 declared governor posts, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) biggest defeat since military rule ended in 1999, following its first-ever presidential loss last month to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna, and insurgency-hit Adamawa but retained Rivers state and won mostly in the south-east, securing eight governorships; results remain outstanding in Taraba and inconclusive in Imo, while elections were not held in seven states. The APC's historic gains relegated the once-dominant PDP to a regional party strong only in the south-east and Niger Delta, though the APC failed to win any oil-producing states, posing challenges for Buhari's administration regarding revenue and militants. Although violence marred some areas due to rivalry and power struggles, the elections were overall more peaceful than previous years. The APC's retention of Lagos means, for the first time since 1999, the president's party will control the commercial capital when Buhari takes office.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Visitors can use an app to trigger online information like videos and band interviews from physical items like signs and posters at the festival site. Festival director Caroline Maclennan explained this augmented reality experience enhances enjoyment for attendees and allows global access to festival content, including information, interviews, ticket purchasing, and the event atmosphere, with updates available before and during the festival.

Several Birmingham schools, including Park View Academy and Nansen Primary, face termination of their funding agreements after Ofsted rated them inadequate, while Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School received warnings they could lose funding unless serious concerns about governance, student safety (including allowing extremist speakers at Park View), lack of spiritual/moral development, segregation, and an unbalanced curriculum are urgently addressed; an anonymous head teacher described feeling undermined by parents and isolated until the Trojan Horse scandal broke, Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw noted a culture of fear and intimidation aimed at imposing a narrow ideology, the Park View Trust plans to legally challenge the reports, parents accused inspectors of bias with loaded questions, and Birmingham City Council will install a temporary governing board at Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was arrested at Tehran Airport last April, spent time in solitary confinement, and was sentenced to five years in jail in September on undisclosed charges of allegedly plotting to topple the Iranian government; her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizes the UK government for insufficient action, describes her appeal as secretive and unpredictable (potentially quashing, reducing, or increasing her sentence), notes she felt suicidal and went on hunger strike but shows more resilience now, and believes she is a diplomatic bargaining chip, while their two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with her grandparents after her passport was confiscated, has lost her English fluency, and Richard is trying to obtain a visa to visit them, and Amnesty International UK calls her a prisoner of conscience held for peacefully exercising her rights and hopes the appeal results in her immediate release.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose is on trial at Ipswich Crown Court for gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution alleges her conduct was criminal, claiming she failed to detect swollen optic discs during the test and refer Vinnie for further investigation. This alleged failure allowed a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure and causing his preventable death, as her performance fell far below expected standards for an optometrist. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg set up meetings between a woman and a man he found via an adult website and filmed them having sex. He was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing the woman into sexual activity and intercourse between September 2013 and September 2014, and of intentionally causing her sister and father to view sexual images and behaving threateningly on Christmas Day 2014. After denying the charges, the victim stated she felt "blackmailed." Sheriff George Way remitted the case to the High Court for sentencing, where Lady Wolffe emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's abhorrence. Weatherhogg, a first offender placed on the sex offenders register, was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, led by Stuart Thompson's 56, Gary Wilson's unbeaten 41, and William Porterfield's 39, after an early blow saw Paul Stirling dismissed for a duck; Afghanistan chased down the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56, Mohammad Shahzad's 47, and Najeeb Tarakai's 27, with Amir Hamza (2-23) the only multiple wicket-taker; Porterfield felt Ireland fell short of a big score and didn't execute well with the ball, and they were also without injured paceman Boyd Rankin, who is expected back for the ODIs starting March 15th, with the second T20 to be played on Friday.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m, but the total cost including fees and wages will reach £106.8m; former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation, which he denies, and a Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer; Barcelona denies any tax crime but made a complimentary tax payment of €13.55m to cover potential interpretations of the tax liability, asserting their original payment was correct, though it remains unconfirmed whether the case will now be dropped.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September; UK Metropolitan Police officers went to Thailand to review the investigation into their murders and have now completed their work, returning to compile a report and update the families. Thai police are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, who allegedly confessed and are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty, though Thai police deny reports they retracted their confessions. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns to Thai authorities over DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of suspects, leading to the UK police visit after the Thai PM agreed to allow it following a prior rejection; post-mortems showed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with Thai police stating DNA found on Witheridge matched the suspects.

Virtual reality is being embedded in reality as a tool by professionals like journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers to enhance understanding and engagement. Specific applications include VR films by the UK's National Autistic Society to simulate autism experiences, Alzheimer's Research UK's dementia simulation "A Walk Through Dementia", retailers like Ikea and Westfield using VR for product visualization and marketing, healthcare providers using it for live surgery training, phobia treatment, and PTSD therapy for soldiers, and educational platforms such as Google Expeditions for virtual field trips and language learning apps. While VR shows promise in transforming learning and engagement in education, its adoption faces hurdles like hardware and computing costs for schools.

The Su-24 jet's black box was opened in Moscow before journalists and diplomats, with Russian investigation head Nikolai Primak noting missing flight data, though the box could help resolve the dispute over the jet's location when hit by Turkish F-16s on 24 November. Turkey claims the Russian jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, while Russia insists it was shot down within Syria, an event that sparked a crisis leading to Russian sanctions including a holiday ban costing Turkey billions and demands for an apology, exacerbated by President Putin's accusations of Turkish subservience to the US and Islamization. The attack resulted in the pilot's death, navigator's rescue, and the death of a marine sent to rescue them along with a destroyed helicopter. An analysis of the black box is expected next week.

The Scotland women's team, unbeaten in five qualifiers, faces crucial matches against Iceland (ranked 20th, one place above Scotland) at Falkirk and in Reykjavik to determine group winners and secure automatic qualification for next summer's finals in the Netherlands, avoiding past heartbreak from previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, a cause of significant concern for players like 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Evans and veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay; with 12 of the 20-strong squad playing abroad—Evans herself recently winning the Bundesliga and interacting with stars like Ribery and Robben—they believe their experience in top leagues like Germany's enhances the national team by bringing different playing styles and high-level training, complementing the improving Scottish league.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no perfect solution ("magic bullet") to fix the council tax system, which has inherent problems from its start that have worsened due to a lack of modification. While Professor Kenneth Gibb's review noted property taxes are widely used among OECD countries and considered stable, difficult to avoid, and beneficial for housing markets, they cause confusion over whether they tax wealth or charge for services and are seen as unfair for not linking to current income. In contrast, local income tax is perceived as fairer but creates difficulties for local authorities due to income volatility and limited ability to vary rates for local priorities; he emphasized reform is inevitably difficult and complex due to past experiences. The commission will hold public consultations before reporting in the autumn, as the Scottish government considers the current council tax unfair and awaits the commission's findings on fairer alternatives.

Apple implemented two-step verification for iCloud backups to prevent third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker from accessing data, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted device for access or purchases on new devices; previously, this protection didn't apply to backups. Elcomsoft's CEO confirmed the changes block his software, now also triggering email notifications for backup downloads, but he expressed concerns about the difficult-to-remember 14-character recovery key being lost or stolen. Security experts argued two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all major tech companies, while Apple CEO Tim Cook acknowledged the company needs to more aggressively encourage users to enable it and use stronger passwords following the celebrity photo incident.

UKIP, winning May's election, spent £2,956,737, while the Conservatives allocated £2,980,815; the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 but lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, and Labour, coming second, spent £1,027,339; campaign spending from 23 January to polling day cost UKIP 68p per vote, Conservatives 79p, Lib Dems £1.45, and Labour 26p; the Green Party, fourth, spent £534,249 at 43p per vote; including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest spenders totalled £9,347,087, according to the Electoral Commission, with all parties except Labour spending more than in 2009.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join Torquay United, a National League rival, and could face his former club on 18 February; he has previous experience with Aldershot, Exeter, and clubs in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, recommended to manager Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, joins from Irish clubs Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, subject to international clearance. Nicholson described Anderson as the leader-type he needed despite limited games and Keating as young, raw, but incredibly hungry. Torquay are four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham and was later pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare incident confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority which stated such episodes can occur without underlying health issues and that investigations into prevention are ongoing; the gelding, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, had previously won the Gold Cup trial and Hennessy Gold Cup, and despite a history of post-race ataxia causing overheating and wobbling, showed no such symptoms on this day, with the report concluding his death resulted from the rare haemorrhage, not his past condition.

Several MSPs, including Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie, gave farewell speeches to the Scottish Parliament before the May 5 election, with Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick visibly emotional during Salmond and McNeil's addresses. Salmond, former First Minister, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse but not divided, welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill while criticizing it as insufficient, and lightened the moment with jokes before emphasizing the honour of serving. McNeil warned Holyrood must learn from Westminster regarding committee scrutiny and accountability, while Goldie humorously remarked on her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service.

Emma Watson has been cast as Belle in an upcoming film, with Dan Stevens playing the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston; Josh Gad will portray Gaston's sidekick LeFou, Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, and an unspecified star will voice Mrs. Potts, directed by Bill Condon, filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May for a US cinema release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will inform relatives of the 96 fans who died in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster about potential charges against suspects at a private meeting; this follows new inquests last year that found the fans were unlawfully killed, with 15 suspects under investigation for causing the disaster and eight others being probed for police conduct afterward, and Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son died, described the wait as a long struggle while hoping this marks the journey's end and emphasizing the families' sole demand for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages hurled over its wall, with a nearby resident witnessing this four times in two weeks, and a former inmate claiming the prison is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, also alleging drone deliveries. The Ministry of Justice states staff work hard to stop contraband but acknowledges more must be done, with the Justice Secretary seeking improved tools for the problem, while noting no drone evidence at Chelmsford and citing new laws allowing up to two-year jail sentences for smuggling packages over walls; the prison is also engaging local residents to discuss the issue.

Brian Wright, 55, admitted hitting Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady, with his car outside Bedford Road Lower School last December, causing serious head injuries that placed her in residential care, but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun; the court heard Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light as Mrs Blackburn was escorting pedestrians across the road, Wright expressed deep remorse for turning her "world upside down," and the trial continues.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the latter. She will miss the Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies, as the event in April conflicts with her final year exams in May, prioritizing her degree despite being gutted. Muir aims for the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and feels she has scope for at least two or three more Olympics in the future.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared after a Christmas party in Dublin in December 2000; a search involving excavations began in May 2024 at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod beside the R112 and River Liffey, expected to last weeks. Earlier in 2024, six detectives conducted a full review, enhancing CCTV footage showing Deely talking to a man in black outside his Baggot Street workplace, likely while returning for an umbrella, and the same man following him later on Haddington Road. Police released the footage in April and renewed appeals, as the unidentified man in black remains sought.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to wrist injuries, defeated Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in the first round, securing his first Grand Slam win since 2014, and will next face Pouille or Young in the same draw quarter as Murray. In the same half, Kyrgios came from two sets down to beat Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 after rain delays and will play Lopez next, who also rallied from two sets down to defeat Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3. Berdych and Tsonga both recorded routine victories, beating Becker and Monaco respectively.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints over a contentious penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, but resolved the issue by meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou and apologizing, though their FTF insisted they never accused anyone of corruption, only criticized the referee's appointment. Morocco, having been banned and fined $1m by CAF for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, had their participation reinstated and fine reduced to $50,000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both nations confirmed their participation in the 2017 qualifying draw, with Tunisia placed in Group A versus Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth straight finals appearance should they qualify.

McLaren, once an F1 powerhouse with 182 wins, 12 drivers' titles, and eight constructors' crowns, now faces a significant slump, currently aiming for merely 4th or 3rd on the grid. This decline began in 2013 with chassis problems and is exacerbated by unreliable Honda power units, contrasting sharply with their past dominance, particularly during their successful Honda era (1988-1991) with Senna and Prost winning 15 of 16 races in 1988, and later successes with Hakkinen around 1998-99. The team's history has been cyclical, alternating between triumph and decline, including a dip in the 1970s reversed when Ron Dennis took control, building them into champions. Recent setbacks include the 2007 spy scandal exclusion and the 2009 'lie-gate' controversy. Despite Dennis's return after the disastrous 2013 season and the presence of top drivers like Alonso, who joined believing in a revived Honda partnership, wins have dried up. However, Dennis insists McLaren will soon challenge Mercedes' dominance, believing the car is now competitive and Honda's engine will improve, aiming to deliver future championships and restore the team's reputation.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014; police arriving later found people still present and evidence alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST, leading to a three-month closure order. License holder Colleen O'Neill was charged with two counts and James Thomas with one count of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, with the defence admitting licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the bar was run improperly into the morning. The judge stated it was "as bad a case" as he had encountered, criticized O'Neill's "appalling record", and expressed concern he could not impose a custodial sentence; O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record by making eight three-pointers against the Portland Trail Blazers, finishing with 45 points and nine assists to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory after overcoming a 13-point deficit, with Klay Thompson adding 26 points; elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit by starting the second half with a 39-8 run to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, as Pau Gasol recorded 16 points and 15 rebounds while the Heat shot poorly and Dwyane Wade managed only nine points.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were initially led to believe Dutch YouTube star Bas van Velzen was a competition winner there for a dead-ball masterclass, but were surprised when he revealed exceptional free-kick skills far exceeding those of a regular fan; van Velzen, known for his online free-kick videos, wowed the players and enjoyed pretending to be less skilled initially before showcasing his talent, finding satisfaction in their reactions.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, who are diagnosed with breast cancer can significantly reduce their risk of dying by undergoing oophorectomy (ovary removal), with a Canadian study of 676 patients showing a 62% reduction in breast cancer death and a 65% reduction in all-cause mortality for BRCA1 carriers, though this benefit was not observed in BRCA2 carriers; the protective effect was strongest when the surgery was performed soon after diagnosis, particularly within two years, and the 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%, with researchers recommending the procedure be discussed as part of initial treatment for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer, especially for those with estrogen-receptor negative cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80 (the Carolinian) shortly before 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on the tracks. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, experienced a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes after the accident on Norfolk-Southern property. None of the 166 passengers aboard were injured, though one man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. Authorities reported the couple was pronounced dead at the scene, and a scrap metal collector suggested the couple may have lived in a homeless camp and struggled with crossing the tracks using a grocery cart.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level Medellin cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, worked for 27 years as an undercover informant for the DEA after providing information on his former associates, aiding in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega; the DEA promised him US citizenship in exchange for his unpaid service, but upon retirement due to declining health, he has not received it and faces deportation, now living illegally in the US. Toro fears he will be killed if sent back to Colombia and remains in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport to collect social security benefits, with his temporary visa expired, while the DEA refused to help after he went public, leaving him prepared to go into hiding despite his handler calling the situation "government bureaucracy at its worst."

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly using the new '.sucks' domain to extract high fees from celebrities such as Kevin Spacey and companies like YouTube, Visa, and Bank of America to protect their reputations. Vox Populi sells the domains to trademark holders for $2,499 per year but plans to offer them to the public for only $10 starting in September, prompting an industry advisory board to label it a coercive "shakedown scheme." ICANN, which initially approved the domain, has asked US and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, potentially leading to a breach of contract.

In 1988, a baby boy's body was found wrapped in a blanket in a Sainsbury's bag floating on Windmill Pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, discovered by teenagers. After 27 years, police exhumed the body during a case review; DNA analysis matched it to a relative, leading investigators to identify and arrest the mother on suspicion of infanticide. She explained she had concealed her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone who was stillborn, and placed the body in the pond before it was found. The infanticide charge was dropped due to her account, but she remains on bail while the CPS considers charging her for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. Originally buried unnamed under a wooden cross, the baby was reinterred as Peter after DNA exoneration confirmed no foul play, with a headstone provided by the stillbirth charity Hana's Gift for the reburial at Weasenham St Peter churchyard on the 26th anniversary of the discovery.

Taxi driver Michael Young was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks after Hicks suffered severe brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires 24-hour care from his mother when he jumped from Young's moving taxi at over 20mph in Bath in 2010; Young mistakenly believed Hicks planned to avoid payment and drove him back to the rank against his will, leading the High Court to rule this constituted unlawful imprisonment, entitling Hicks to damages reduced by 50% from the family's request (expected to be hundreds of thousands of pounds), plus a £250 sum, with the final amount pending a potential appeal hearing.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms brought tornado reports, including one near Goddard which moved northeast missing Wichita but threatening other areas; severe weather expert Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are most dangerous. Additional tornado sightings occurred near Aetna in southwestern Kansas, while Missouri also faced impacts with a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, and roof damage, alongside large hail reported in Farmington. More storms were forecast for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold plans to aggressively pursue Lyoto Machida in their middleweight fight in New Jersey, describing himself as the "bull" to Machida's "matador" and aiming to cut off the cage, dominate, and exploit perceived weaknesses in Machida's game, including limited hip movement and ground chances, while seeking a fourth consecutive win and a title shot; Machida, coming off a victory, expresses confidence in his own style and preparation for eight weeks, believes he can apply his technique to win and also earn a title shot with victory, acknowledges seeing some potential weaknesses in Rockhold but prefers to feel out the fight, and expects a competitive bout despite the mutual respect both fighters hold for each other's skills and history.

A light general aviation AeroStar plane landed without deploying its landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding on its belly with propellers striking the tarmac before the pilot applied full throttle and took off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog Buddy, where pilot Chris Georgaklis, 85, landed safely despite the damage; the incident, witnessed and filmed, was attributed to human error or mechanical fault and is under FAA investigation.

Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré's underperformance but vowed to support the Manchester City midfielder until at least the season's end, despite City being open to offers for him in the summer during a squad overhaul; Pellegrini dismissed claims Touré needed rest, while goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players had let down their manager, who faces his own future questions. Separately, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned defender Aaron Cresswell against moving to City, citing the limited playing time experienced by previous English signings like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, despite City's interest in the homegrown player.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge" who lived in Britain for over 20 years under an assumed name after fleeing Italy in the 1990s, was convicted in absentia in 1999 for Cosa Nostra membership and sentenced to seven years; after losing an extradition battle in February 2015, his prison sentence expired in October 2015 under Italian law (as more than double the penalty time had passed), leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant and allowing him to remain in the UK, though his conviction stands and the case must still go to Italy's supreme court; the proceedings drew criticism for wasted time and resources, with legal experts blaming an administrative error by the CPS in failing to appeal a 2014 decision on time, contributing to the sentence expiration.

Mr mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is a joint 7-2 co-favourite with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre (ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury) in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday; this will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and McCoy's final book of rides for his retirement day will be confirmed on Friday morning, with his retirement announcement having come after winning on Mr mole at Newbury in February, while other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, with her body found 33 days later hidden near their home; Ritter avoided seeing crime scene photos for decades on her then-husband's advice but recently viewed them, expressing horror at her daughter's condition and a desire for revenge. The case remained Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years, with an initial charge against a neighbor dropped due to insufficient evidence, until DNA evidence from Marcia's clothing matched Barrett after his 2006 arrest for another murder, leading to his 2009 conviction for second-degree murder and a 44-year prison sentence.

Rory McIlroy considers winning the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam as "unthinkable" and a "career-long goal," aiming to join the exclusive group of players who have won all four majors. His devastating final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011, which he identifies as the most important day of his career, provided crucial lessons that helped him secure subsequent major victories. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, the 25-year-old believes the course suits him and feels confident about winning multiple green jackets, emphasizing that getting the first victory is paramount. McIlroy treats the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the immense pressure and hype surrounding Augusta, focusing solely on playing his best golf during tournaments, and acknowledges he would be profoundly disappointed to retire without achieving this feat.

The passage covers several trending stories: four rainbows appeared over New York after heavy rain, photographed by Amanda Curtis; rural Chinese families hiring exotic dancers for funerals now face a government crackdown; Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a UK interviewer's questions about his private life; the viral #KylieJennerChallenge involved lip-plumping by sucking on jars; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisited her past with filmmakers' help; a bomb-themed prom-posal led to accusations of racism after school intervention; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast"; Johnny Depp appeared unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer; a pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"; and a military dad photobombed his son, all trending recently.

New figures reveal 272 children in England were hospitalized last year with disabilities from foetal alcohol syndrome, though experts warn this is likely vastly under-diagnosed and the true scale is much larger; research by the World Health Organisation suggests at least one in 100 UK babies (approximately 7,500 annually) suffer learning, behavioural, and physical problems like deformed limbs due to alcohol exposure in the womb. A case study illustrates the severe impact, such as 15-year-old Niamh Brown who requires help dressing, has no sense of danger, and cannot live independently. Other associated medical issues include problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current UK government advice for pregnant women is not to drink alcohol, but if they do, to consume no more than two units twice weekly, although an expert recommends complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as 'Boomerang Boy', was jailed for six years after his masked axe-wielding robbery attempt at Shildon Post Office and Stores was thwarted. Bursting in at 8 PM on March 15 and demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, McKerry was rugby tackled to the floor by shop owner Sab Dhillon. As the men wrestled with McKerry still holding the axe, Dhillon's wife Sam struck him twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him while her husband revealed his face to security cameras before police arrived and arrested him. McKerry, who had a long history of crime starting at age 12 including 80 arrests by age 15, earned his nicknames because he always returned home after committing offences.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after an alleged incident involving a young woman at a Canadian barracks party following an ice hockey tournament; they have been granted bail in Nova Scotia under strict conditions requiring them to reside at the Stadacona naval base, surrender their passports, remain employed by the Royal Navy, avoid contacting the victim and six witnesses, and stay within the province until their trial, with the offences carrying potential prison sentences of up to 14 years and investigations still pending.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son RJ suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare genetic skin disease affecting only about 70 people globally, causing his skin to appear red, inflamed, scaly, and resemble a scald; while out shopping, Mrs. Jackson was accosted by armed police after a stranger mistakenly reported her for child abuse due to RJ's appearance, reflecting broader public ignorance and leading to frequent taunts, bullying (often from adults), and social exclusion like being denied entry to play areas. Despite the lack of a cure, requiring constant skin care with creams like Vaseline applied several times daily which severely impacts the family's sleep, and RJ experiencing symptoms like soreness and itchiness, Mrs. Jackson discovered the condition through an online support group after an initial misdiagnosis and remains dedicated to her son's care, emphasizing his beauty and resilience.

Campaigners are celebrating as Transport for London removes the controversial "Are You Beach Body Ready?" Protein World adverts featuring model Renee Somerfield, which prompted widespread backlash including a petition with over 50,000 signatures, public defacements, and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority for promoting unhealthy body image; TfL confirmed the removal coincides with the end of the paid three-week advertising period, noting customer feedback will influence similar future ads, while Protein World defended their unphotoshopped campaign as targeting health-conscious individuals, dismissing critics as an "irrational minority" despite receiving threats and facing an ongoing ASA assessment of the complaints.

Rail firms planned significant fare hikes, including an 87% increase by First Great Western (FGW) off-peak returns from Charlbury to London (rising from £33.30 to £62.40), prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to demand FGW urgently review the changes as they affected his Witney constituency; despite pledges by major parties like Cameron's Conservatives and Labour to freeze or cap fares, other companies also implemented substantial rises, such as London Midlands increasing a Crewe to Northampton first-class single from £30 to £37 and Virgin boosting a Stafford to Liverpool anytime return by 24.5% (£26.50 to £33), though Virgin defended its hikes as primarily affecting cheaper Virgin-only fares with an overall West Coast increase of just 1.65%.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after thugs threw bricks at his Oldham home; initially pelting his window with stones, they threw a brick through the front door when he confronted them, striking him in the face and causing a severe injury that emergency surgery could not repair, leaving him permanently blind in his left eye. The attack occurred just three weeks after his marriage to Elaine, 54, while they were writing thank-you cards, around 11 pm on April 18th. Police are investigating but state there appears to be no known motive, suggesting it might have been yobs "messing around," although they acknowledge the result is a "permanent disability." Having lived there most of his life without prior problems, Mr. Young stated he no longer feels safe in his home, and the couple plans to move to Southport due to fear of living in their neighborhood.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension until the end of the 2016 season after successfully returning from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident last April that also claimed his father's life; he underwent ankle surgery and made his playing comeback during the club's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's exceptional character and tireless work since the tragedy, expressing the club's delight at his return and hope the new contract provides confidence for him to express himself this summer, noting his good form in training and Abu Dhabi.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford is cancer-free after battling aggressive neuroblastoma, a rare cancer affecting specialized nerve cells diagnosed in fewer than 100 UK children yearly, which he had in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones; during treatment including 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, he felt stronger by decorating his protective radiotherapy mask like a ninja turtle and wearing superhero costumes, leading to recognition like a Cancer Research UK Little Star Award and becoming the face of their charity campaign, while Nickelodeon sent him presents, and he will now have regular check-ups.

Tim Sherwood advises 19-year-old Jack Grealish to prioritize establishing himself in the Aston Villa first team over choosing between his international options with England or the Republic of Ireland, following his impressive performance in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool; Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish must secure a regular starting role at Villa first, and while the international decision is ultimately Grealish's alone, both he and Grealish's father Kevin agree that concentrating on club football is paramount, with Grealish reportedly split between the two countries and expected to decide at the end of the season.

Private jet landing fees vary significantly and are a substantial expense for wealthy travelers, with Japan's airports (Haneda at £4,559, Narita at £3,728, Kansai at £3,594) being the most expensive globally for a 767-400 aircraft, followed by Toronto (£3,461), Darwin (£3,059), Bristol (£2,929), LaGuardia (£2,630), Dublin (£2,729), and Salzburg (£2,530); private jet usage is growing (2.5 million US flights, 705,000 European flights) and peaks during major events like the Super Bowl ( costing up to £54,000 for a round trip) and Monaco Grand Prix, with popular routes including Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan to Rome ($5,880 one way), while unexpected hubs like Darwin, Bristol, and Salzburg feature in the top ten highest landing fees.

Cooper, a Labrador retriever who eats very quickly, devoured an entire McDonald's ice cream cone in one bite during an outing, contrasting with the smaller dog Daisy's few dainty licks, prompting his owner Katie Gallegos to ensure Daisy gets her fill first; this behavior was captured in a video viewed over seven million times, drawing mixed reactions of amusement and criticism about feeding dogs ice cream, which Gallegos defended as a safe weekly treat noting her previous dog lived to 19 with similar habits and Cooper is healthy, further evidence of their love for fast food included another video showing Cooper gulping down a Starbucks "pup-uccino" (whipped cream).

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal after serving as interim manager since Allan Johnston quit in February; Locke, formerly Johnston's assistant since last summer, has lost only once in seven games and will hold a press conference on Friday following the contract signing with chairman Jim Mann.

Florida mother Jessica Kemp accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because he wears Doterra essential oils (lavender, chamomile, sandalwood) applied to his head and neck, which she claims help him stay calm and focused; teachers stated the oils smelled and were a distraction to other students, prompting a letter from the school board calling the oils a "problem," but Kemp vowed to continue using them despite the threat, and the Lake County School District later confirmed they would not suspend Logan as it was considered a health issue.

A massive fire on Wednesday at 3 PM destroyed the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, obliterating 90 condos and causing the building to collapse; the intense flames, visible from three miles away and melting paint on nearby buildings, prevented twelve fire crews from entering, though offshore winds aided their efforts. The complex, used seasonally as holiday homes between May and November, saw resident Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, who lived there, express devastation over losing everything, while the fire chief confirmed investigations into claims the blaze started near a parked car.

The Queen, nearing 89, enjoyed a spring ride on her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park, choosing a silk scarf over a helmet due to her hairstyle. She has ridden since receiving her first Shetland pony Peggy at age four, owning famous mounts like Betsy and Surprise, and continues breeding fell ponies at Hampton Court and highland ponies at Balmoral. Although a persistent knee injury has reduced her riding and ended her trooping the colour on horseback, she remains actively involved with her horses, which are sometimes ridden by her grandchildren. Her lifelong passion includes breeding fell ponies, an ancient Cumbrian breed used historically by Romans and Vikings as pack animals, valued today for their docile, hardy nature and popular for riding.

An argument over noise between Brisbane neighbours Leon Yeaman and Phillip Pama resulted in Yeaman's death from a single punch allegedly thrown by Pama during a confrontation outside their homes; Yeaman, described as a loud and sometimes drunk 55-year-old, was making noise around 9 PM while Pama, a married father of three with no history of violence and needing sleep for a 3 AM shift, confronted him; the punch occurred during an escalation where Pama claimed he acted blindly while being pushed, leading to Yeaman being pronounced dead at the scene by 11 PM; Pama was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail requiring passport surrender, a 6 PM-2 AM curfew, and twice-weekly police reporting, with his next court date set for May 18.

Jilted 52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova tried to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship for a classmate, offering 100,000 rubles (£1,400); police conducted a sting operation where an undercover officer recorded Simonova detailing her desire for the boy to suffer unbearable pain, specifying broken limbs, kidney damage to cause slow bleeding, and her intention to "finish" him herself; she handed over expense money and was arrested immediately, now facing 15 years in prison for attempted murder; Vanya expressed relief, hoping authorities would "throw away the key."

José Mourinho, Chelsea's 52-year-old football manager, prays daily and speaks with God about his personal life but never about football or with his wife, emphasizing his separation of professional and family life; he asserts he is a good person who supports others despite his competitive professional persona, acknowledges making mistakes in his high-pressure career, and works with the World Food Programme against poverty, having experienced it himself and involving his family in events like the Victoria's Secret show and Hunger Games premiere, while attending church regularly only in Portugal and facing recent fines related to his professional conduct.

Bob Barker, the host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years until 2007, returned to host the show for the first time in eight years on April 1st, appearing spry at 91 and handling the first game, "Lucky Seven," before current host Drew Carey took over for the rest of the episode, with Barker performing well despite his long absence.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. early Friday after allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE, facing felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property; the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave, while he was due to be arraigned later that day without an attorney listed. Baldwin, posted to the foreign missions branch handling diplomatic activities, was one of two recent agency embarrassments, occurring days after a high-ranking supervisor was placed on leave due to misconduct allegations also under investigation, and amidst ongoing inspector general probes into a prior March 4 incident involving two officials allegedly drunkenly driving into a secure White House area.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38 from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a close-up image of a hungry lion at a city safari park; he exited his car, crept within 10 feet, and lay on the ground armed only with a camera, managing a few shots before the shutter sound alerted the lion, which jumped aggressively, forcing him to scramble rapidly back into his car for safety. Saeed, who was initially near his open car door and sat on the ground like prey to capture the lion's character and status, admits it was a close encounter and he would not repeat the dangerous act.

New York City police released an image of a distinctive tattoo—a heart with a ribbon bearing the name "Monique" topped by a rose—found on the right leg of an unidentified woman discovered lying unconscious and pronounced dead on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn's Gravesend section; the woman, estimated between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification, and authorities await a medical examiner's report on her cause of death while seeking public information through Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple returning from the UK in 2009, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over 18 months in Nelson because they couldn't afford traditional property; their $25,000 wood and steel home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass, spring water, gas-powered stove and hot water, achieves near self-sufficiency primarily via solar panels ($25 power bill), and places them surrounded by nature with their cat in a cypress-lined interior near trees and a brook.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher on early literacy tests than students who either used iPads individually or did not use them at all; this study, involving 352 students, attributes the improvement to collaborative learning specifically around the technology, suggesting schools should reconsider tablet use in early grades for maximum effectiveness, and the findings will be presented at the International Communication Association conference.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, China, owned by farmer Ms. Duan, has become an internet sensation by mastering walking on its two front trotters, as shown in a heartwarming video where it takes unsteady steps while foraging, nearly tipping over but regaining balance; nicknamed "super pig," it attracts villagers and has thousands of online fans, and it's noted that a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo previously gained similar fame in China.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Dale Coyne Racing pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone’s car, which spun while exiting the pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips’ leg; Phillips received stitches for a cut at the infield care center before being released, while rain caused traction issues for many drivers, and Dracone failed to finish the race, placing 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, confessed to murdering his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, just four days after their marriage due to jealousy over men looking at her; CCTV footage and a neighbor's account revealed he dragged her into their garden, smashed her head into concrete paving 11 times, punched her face 10 times, and shot her five times in the face at point-blank range after calling her a slut and whore; Severiano then fled in a stolen neighbor's car, crashed it during his getaway, and was arrested with police finding four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle, and he now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed in a candid interview that severe anxiety nearly led her to take her own life, as a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family relationships made her feel extremely isolated and unable to see a way forward or the point in continuing, despite struggling in her younger years she has now found some peace and accepts she is an anxious person, though she previously felt she missed a "guidebook to life" watching others cope; Wilson emphasizes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked, arguing this connection must be acknowledged to address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women, noting Beyond Blue reports one in three Australian women experience anxiety in their lifetime, a condition she sees as quickly becoming the "new depression."

Elena Curtin, a Portland woman who was seven months pregnant, found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom in November 2014; after the woman refused to leave, Curtin struck her with a crowbar, leading to second-degree assault charges. Prosecutors subsequently dropped the charge before trial, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law allowing force against intruders. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin, attempting to draw the boyfriend back into addiction, and had previously gotten high with him in the apartment; they share a five-year-old child and later reconciled. Curtin gave birth in January, is now living with her parents, and the boyfriend has not been involved with their new child, avoiding a mandatory nearly six-year prison sentence.

Gemma the pit bull in California was filmed eating treats when her owner secretly added a broccoli spear; she immediately showed disgust while chewing it, then spit it onto the floor, raising concerns the children she lives with might copy her dislike of greens, and when not eating, she enjoys sleeping and being with her human family.

HSBC apologised after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page, as the address for the discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards page (shut down since 2011) was taken over by a porn business once its registration expired; the bank removed the hyperlink upon discovering the error, denied any association with the external site in an apology, and insisted its main website and internet banking services remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after his Clinton home caught fire early Sunday, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom. During an 11-minute call, Marcus calmly provided firefighters with precise directions to their location, including navigating the back hallway and identifying a black door, while simultaneously soothing his panicked sister by telling her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, handed Marcus out to another rescuer, and gave Aaliyah a gas mask.
